He noted that many websites run on a business model that lets users have free content in exchange for their personal data, which allows them to harvest vast amounts of personal information, which in turn can make the internet a dangerous place to retain any kind of privacy or to discuss important but sensitive topics.Inventor of World Wide Web calls for crackdown on fake newsSince Sir Tim wrote that message, the world was rocked by the Cambridge Analytica scandal and a whole host of other revelations about the amount of data being collected on private people and how it is being used.The second challenge he noted was that it is “too easy for misinformation to spread on the web”. Noting that “most people find news and information on the web through just a handful of social media sites and search engines”, he described how websites spreading hoaxes, and false stories can do so relatively easily, and that the system can be gamed to spread that even more quickly.Third, he said that online political advertising “needs transparency and understanding”. Such advertising is become incredibly sophisticated, he noted, and when combined with the vast amount of data companies like Facebook are tracking can make it very easy to manipulate those people who see it.The scandal over political advertising in events such as the 2016 election and the Brexit vote is still continuing, and campaigners still criticise the relatively limited transparency that has been introduced on platforms that claim to be looking to limit it.A year later, in 2018, he shared another set of challenges, which largely related to the fact that the world has crossed over the point where more people use the web than don’t. That brings a whole host of questions of access and openness, he suggested.The threats that are posed to the web still very much exist, he noted. “But I remain committed to making sure the web is a free, open, creative space — for everyone,” he wrote last year.By closing the digital ide and helping people get online, stopping the control of the web lying with a small number of very big companies, and by making the discussion around the future of the web more erse, he claimed those threats could be avoided.Sir Tim has been consistent in arguing that the web is really a communal endeavour – and calling on that community to help save it from the threats it is facing.“I may have invented the web, but all of you have helped to create what it is today,” he wrote in 2017. “All the blogs, posts, tweets, photos, videos, applications, web pages and more represent the contributions of millions of you around the world building our online community.”That was a vision that was present in the original proposals for the world wide web, begun 30 years ago today. There, Sir Tim described a vision of CERN staff on the web&nbspas “several thousand people, many of them very creative, all working toward common goals”.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: But Chancellor Philip Hammond has announced a further increase for some workers from  - heres what you need to know.The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over  are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in .The National Living Wage increased from £. to £. for those aged  and over.The  pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April , .From April , the National Living Wage will increase by  pence-an-hour to £..The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in .The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.In Budget , Chancellor Hammond announced that lowest-paid workers will get another pay rise from next year to a minimum of £. per hour.Its a five per cent hike, which will come into force from April, and will benefit around .million workers.Mr Hammond said: From April [the National Living Wage] will rise again, handing a full-time worker a £ annual pay increase.Hammond is aiming to get the wage to £ by .It is dferent to the real living wage which is voluntary and not fixed by the government.The National Minimum Wage is the amount workers aged under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount dfers depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage is:From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage will be:The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not title: what happens ireland no brexit
story: Heres what you need to know...As far as the EU is concerned, Northern Ireland is part of the UK.If Britain is left with no-deal after the Brexit deadline passes, Northern Ireland is in the same boat.The Republic of Irelandare part of the EU in their own right as a sovereign nation.SoNorthern Ireland fell back on WTO rules, a new customs barrier would suddenly spring up across the Ireland-Northern Ireland border.This creates a big issue.The Good Friday Agreement dictates that people and trade must flow freely between Northern and the Republic of Ireland.A no-deal would break that agreement, and there would suddenly be a more palpable ision between the north and south.The Good Friday Agreement was instrumental in ending the violence in Ireland between southern Nationalists, and northern Unionists.There are some that fear a customs check could reignite violence as the choice of remaining part of the UK becomes more isive once again.How a Brexit deal would accommodate the Good Friday Agreement is a big issue, with a proposed back stop measure.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.It would avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would supposedly be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.However - legal advice provided to the Prime Minister by Attorney General Geoffrey Cox concluded the proposed backstop would stop Britain making trade deals around the world in a separate legal document. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn egged by pro brexit campaigner during visit to mosque
story: The Labour boss was said to have been hit while on a trip to the Muslim Welfare House and Finsbury Park Mosque in North London on Sunday.Sky News reported that the man is said to be a pro-Brexit protester.John Murphy, , was today charged with assault and will appear at Highbury Corner Magistrates Court on March .Murphy allegedly screamed When you vote you get what you vote for as he came from behind and smacked Mr Corbyn with an egg.Diane Abbott, who was with Mr Corbyn at the time, claimed he punched Jeremy very hard and happened to have an egg in his hand.It is understood the alleged attack was not a regular guest at the mosque.politan Police confirmed an egg was thrown at the member of Parliament on Sunday afternoon.Labour sources confirmed Corbyn was unharmed by the event and continued with his programme of events.He was taking part in the annual Visit My Mosque day with Shadow Home secretary Ms Abbott, visiting two venues in his local area.As he went into one he was given several red roses by fans.Mr Corbyn later tweeted: Every year Muslim communities across the country open their doors to people of all faiths and none on #VisitMyMosque Day. Its a fantastic opportunity to build understanding across communities and educate ourselves about our erse communities. Lets build bridges not walls.The Muslim Welfare House in London released a statement after the incident, saying it the attacker had shouted and hurled verbal abuse to the utter shock and disgust of all present.Toufik Kacimi, CEO of the organisation, said: We condemn in the strongest terms this outrageous act which has left everyone shocked.This disgraceful act by this inidual is a sign of the hatred and Islamophobia that sadly abound in our community.We will not let this deter us from cooperating with all groups in building a more cohesive society.Other Labour figures who have been also hit with an egg include ex-Labour boss Ed Miliband, as well as John Prescott, who went on to punch the protester.Last week Mr Corbyn confirmed that his party would get behind a second Brexit referendum, much to the fury of his pro-Brexit voters.But MPs in Leave backing seats warned it could cost the party their seats - and the next election.

title: sands united football team grieving dads
story: But behind their proud smiles, these men all share a secret - every player is a father who has lost a child - and the group play to support each other through their grief, both on and off the pitch.Sadly, the death of a baby is not a rare event and every  minutes in the UK – theof a football match - a baby dies shortly before, during or soon after birth.This is why each player has the name of his lost angel emblazoned on his shirt.It makes me feel like Im doing something for them. Im more motivated to score. We do it for our angels, player Kieran says.The team – which has over  players - was set up by Rob Allen, , after his baby daughter Niamh died in October  at  weeks and  days.While he and his we Charlotte, , had been told at weeks into the pregnancy that she was breach, they had no inkling anything was wrong.Then, days before she was due, a doctor told them there was no heartbeat - and they didnt know why. About one in three stillbirths are unexplained.Our walls just folded in, the carpenter and roofer recalls. It was a horrible, heartbreaking situation to be told that the child you had been planning to welcome home for so long, was not coming.To help him deal with what had happened, Rob started attending his local Sands - stillbirth and neonatal death charity-support group.Then the manager of an old league team he used to play for, Alan, suggested holding a football match to raise money for the charity.They recruited  players who had either lost babies, and raised £,.We saw that it had given those men an opportunity to talk about their experiences, Rob explains. And because everyone had got a huge amount out of it we decided to put the wires out and set up a permanent team.Because were playing in memory of our lost children, theres an extra drive - it gives us that little bit extra in the last  minutes of a game and makes us more of a unit than other Sunday teams who treat it as more of a jokey kickabout, dont mindthey win or lose and might turn up a bit drunk, he adds.Those who have signed up arent just men who have lost their own children, but include a player whose twin was lost at birth, and another whose sister lost a baby. They have very much felt the impact, explains Rob.Then theres those who have suffered from PTSD after nearly losing their partners as well as their baby during childbirth, and have experienced flashbacks and nightmares as a result. One had to seek further help because he was having suicidal thoughts, and his mind was telling him to join his baby.Were now in a time when there is more of a focus on male mental health, and encouraging men to talk and not bottle it up, says Rob. Thats where football comes in - it can feel accessible whereas sitting in a room and being asked whats your name  Whats your story  can feel daunting.The success of the club shows how much this service is needed. Theres already  people interested in starting their own Sands football teams around the UK, and theres been interest in the club in the UK, France, Belgium and Russia.Of Niamhs legacy, Rob - who has a five-year-old son Alfie and has also welcomed newborn daughter Iris - adds: Shes inspired me to do something that has helped local people, and is now touching those across the country and across the world.For Ross Coniam, , from Watford, who joined the team last year, the camaraderie amongst his teammates who have all experienced the loss of a child has been overwhelming.“Some men in the group lost children  years, others in the last one or two years but there’s nothing like being able to talk to someone who knows exactly what you’re feeling when you’re down and having a crap day,” says Ross, who lost his daughter Norah last May just hours after she was born. “It’s still such a taboo subject and some of my friends have never talked to me about it because they don’t know how - but talking about it does help.After a smooth pregnancy, Ross and his we Naomi were excited for the birth of their first baby and had no idea anything was wrong.“But as soon as she was delivered, there was panic,” recalls Ross. “Someone pushed the alarm bell and  to  people doctors piled into the room and started working on her because she wasn’t breathing. It took  minutes to resuscitate her and we knew it wasn’t good.”The baby was taken to the special care unit and hooked up to machines to help her breathe - but the doctors told Ross and Naomi there was no brain activity and there was nothing they could do.“It was so hard to take in,” says Ross. “She weighed lbs and looked absolutely perfect, with a gorgeous smattering of dark hair. After family and friends came to see her, we were taken to a side room so we could hold her for the first and last time.The doctors didn’t think she’d breathe more than a few seconds off the machines, but she lasted half an hour – it was a miracle.They named her Norah Faith, the middle name chosen there and then at the hospital when she was first taken away and there was still some hope. It is the name under the badge on Ross’s team shirt, over his heart, and the name at the forefront of his mind when he meets the team.“Not many people have been through what we’ve been through and it’s such a comfort having them there,” says Ross. “I go to Norah’s grave every week and read her stories like The Hungry Caterpillar, like I would have doneshe had been alive, and it can feel so painful and sad. Naomi is pregnant again now –  weeks – and it’s wonderful but I think I’ll be nervous until we’re out the other side.”Kieran Wright, , a warehouse worker from Northampton, understands all too well what it feels to be nervous about a pregnancy, after his fiancé suffered two miscarriages in two years.“She was eight weeks pregnant when she started to have severe stomach pains,” recalls Kieran. “We got to hospital and after a few tests they told us we’d had a miscarriage. It was so hard. All that good news and excitement about the pregnancy and it had all gone in the blink of an eye.For a while afterwards, I struggled to go to work and didn’t want to leave my fiancé. You can’t even say everything’s going to be alright, because it just isn’t.”The second miscarriage happened a year later in similar circumstances. “This time I could barely eat, didn’t talk. I was just in my own little world. I suppose I’d hit rock bottom, he tells us. We named them Casey and Dot.”He heard about a charity match Sands Utd were playing locally and spoke to Rob the founder and decided to sign up. “The first time I met some of the lads I preferred to listen to their stories than talk, but over time I did open up and let all my emotions out and I’ve never felt so supported, he says.After games we go to the clubhouse and we will talk through how were feeling - other times we will go round each others houses.They’ve since had a rainbow baby – Archie – who is now six months old. “If I feel down, he’ll just smile at me and I cheer up,” says Kieran.When a baby dies the feelings of loneliness and isolation can be overwhelming and having other bereaved parents to talk to is vital, and dads, especially, can sometimes be overlooked.This is why Sands is now working with Rob and the team to develop Sands United FC into a model that can be rolled out across the UK, so that more bereaved families can set up teams to channel their grief and help break the silence around baby loss.Already four new teams have been set up in Kent, Warwickshire, Leicester and Rutland and Grimsby and Cleethorpes and Sands United has a firm social media following, numbering almost  followers on Facebook and almost the same amount on Twitter and Instagram.To find out more about Sands Utd, visit sandsutdfc. To contact the Sands helpline, call    or email helpline@sands.org.uk.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexiteers gamble of their lives theresa may deal
story: Look how they are strangling Brexit:Amber Rudd and her mates wrecked Geoffrey Cox’s chances of fixing the backstop. The EU knows those Cabinet rebels will help vote down No Deal.Tory Nick Boles is conspiring with Corbyn over his disastrous “Norway Plus” idea — the worst possible option.Remainer Lords are trying AGAIN to force the Government into a permanent restrictive customs union with Brussels.Most appallingly, ex-Attorney General Dominic Grieve is openly colluding with the French to postpone Brexit for  months, long enough for a second referendum. If MPs vote to delay on March , Theresa May will be virtually powerless to refuse France’s demands. Why does Grieve still have the Tory whip And yet some Brexiteer MPs still think it’s safe to vote down the deal next Tuesday. That the law’s on their side. That we will still leave, but with No Deal.We would love to be proved wrong — but they seem dangerously delusional.Reject the deal, and a non-Brexit they will regret forever and which will destroy their party seems vastly more likely.Brexiteers will have made the biggest gamble of their lives and lost.THE Sun has always liked Prince Harry. title: brexit brexiteers wont back theresa mays deal softer
story: The Government’s efforts to get changes to the backstop have run into a brick wall in Brussels. The EU thinks, with justication, that MPs won’t allow No Deal so it feels under no pressure to make signicant concessions.Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief negotiator, is telling the UK thatit doesn’t like the backstop, it can have a Northern Ireland-only version of it — which the UK has already rejected. One minister fully briefed on the negotiations tells me: “We’re at ‘what the hell do we do ’ time.”But without a change to the backstop, Theresa May’s deal is going down to another heavy defeat on Tuesday.That won’t be the end of the matter, though. For the very next day Parliament will vote against leaving on March  with No Deal. Parliament will then almost certainly vote to request an extension to Article , the two-year process for leaving the EU.At this moment, the UK would be in the EU’s hands. As one weary No source admits: “They’d be in a position of being able to dictate terms.”It would be up to the EU to decide whether to grant an extension, how long it would be for and what conditions would be attached to it. How humiliating: This country’s future would be being determined in Brussels, not Westminster.The EU would almost certainly grant an extension. But what terms it would come with remains to be seen.What should worry those MPs who are voting against Mrs May’s deal because it is not a clean enough Brexit, is what Parliament would do with this extension. I understand that unless the Government indicates that it will allow the Commons to vote on ious Brexit options, an amendment will be tacked on to the extension vote to ensure that “indicative votes” are held.These votes would be on March  and the Commons would move to bind the Government to negotiate what it wants it to.Ministers would have to report back regularly to the Commons on the progress they are making. Mrs May might be in office, but she would not be in power. It is inevitable that the Brexit the Commons would mandate would be softer than Mrs May’s deal.So why, then, are so many Brexiteers not voting for her deal  Well, the problem is that many of them regard it as so flawed that they have no desire to rescue it. They would, in the words of one Cabinet minister: “Rather their hands be clean of all this.”But this isn’t PRACTICAL POLITICS. If Brexiteers won’t back Mrs May’s deal, then Brexit is ONLY GOING TO GET SOFTER.Is there any hope of avoiding this crisis  Today, it looks unlikely. But the DUP does want a deal.While they won’t accept the backstop as it currently is and were, in the words of one source, “not entirely happy” with the proposal Geoffrey Cox took to Brussels, they are eager for an agreement.If progress on the backstop was combined with a commitment from Mrs May that she would step down before phase two of the negotiations, then the deal might pass.I understand that a leading Brexiteer backbencher conveyed this message to influential figures in the Government this week. One normally loyal minister tells me: “If there’s nothing , that is the thing that has to work.”One outcome next week would avoid a crisis: Some progress on the backstop, Mrs May’s deal passing and a new PM coming in to do the next phase of the negotiations. All other roads lead to crisis.But right now, that is where we are headed.LABOUR will, officially, back a second referendum next week.But with as many as  Labour MPs opposed to the idea, it isn’t going to pass the Commons.Jeremy Corbyn has never been enthusiastic about a second referendum – he only backed one to prevent more defections to The Independent Group of MPs.Once he has gone through the motions of supporting one, he will feel free to pivot to other options.This was demonstrated by the fact he had a meeting with the Norway Plus group of MPs this week, who want the UK to stay in the EU single market.A soft Brexit has an obvious appeal for Corbyn. It would offer a solution to the issue while splitting the Tory Party.IT is now looking increasingly likely that the UK won’t be able to get anything on the backstop.“The EU are just not budging,” one of those intimately involved in the negotiations tells me.Bringing back a pretty much unchanged deal for a vote on Tuesday would lead to a heavy defeat for the Government, and probably by a three-figure margin.But there is another option being discussed in government. Gavin Barwell, the Prime Minister’s chief of staff, told ministers this week that one option was to bring to the Commons the proposal that the UK has taken to Brussels. The idea would then be to try to win a vote on that, to prove to the EU that such a change would get the deal through.Right now, one Downing Street source says, there is a “chicken and egg problem” as the EU doesn’t think that what the UK is proposing would get the deal through the Commons, and so doesn’t see the point in engaging with it.Some in government think that doing this would offer a way out of the votes on No Deal and an extension that threaten to create the bitterest Tory split yet over Europe.This strategy is not without risks. It isn’t certain that the Government would win this vote. There is also a danger that holding a vote on a proposal that has been rejected by the EU would end up looking absurd.But walking into a vote knowing that you are going to lose heavily is rarely a sensible governing strategy.ON Wednesday, Alan Duncan urged the Prime Minister’s chief of staff, Gavin Barwell, to have the Government whip against No DealMrs May’s deal is defeated next week.Duncan warned of an eruption from the “moderate” wing of the partythis didn’t happen. Barwell pointed out that Leave ministers have accepted a lot of compromises over the past few years.The exchange demonstrated how dficult the next week will be for the Tories. The votes that would follow Mrs May’s deal failing would make every previous Tory argument over Europe look like small beer.I understand the Government is looking to contain the row through a motion that would say the UK would not leave on March  without a deal, but would try to make clear that it was still an option after that.AS Mrs May was saying there was “no direct correlation between certain crimes and police numbers”, a leaflet from the Tories’ mayoral candidate Shaun Bailey was dropping on London doormats declaring thatthe party took City Hall they would hire , more police “Helping to bring an end to rising crime”.This pledge shows the position the Government has got itself into is politically preposterous.What is needed is more police to deal with the current crisis, then action to stop children from being drawn into these gangs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: They say theres a frightening trend where people think its acceptable to use e-cigarettes at home or in the car.One scientist warned the complacency is similar to how society viewed smoking  years ago.It marks one of the first scientic studies to gauge parents rules about e-cigarette use at home.Researchers at MassGeneral Hospital in the US found parents who vape are much more likely to allow e-cigarettes to be used at home or in their cars, compared with parents who smoke.Dr Jeremy Drehmer, who was one of the leads on the study, said: Our results suggest parents may perceive that it is safe to use e-cigarettes and are not taking the same precautions they do to protect their children from exposure to traditional cigarettes.This study shows that parents who are dual users of e-cigarettes and traditional cigarettes are much less likely to prohibit vaping inside their homes than to prohibit smoking.His team quizzed  parents across ten paediatric clinics across America, including vapers and smokers.They found just  per cent of e-cigarette users and  per cent of dual users had banned vaping at home and in the car.And  per cent of both e-cig users and dual users admitted people used the devices in their cars when kids were present too.Dr Drehmer said this was an alarming trend, and added: We are concerned that parents have been misled by the marketing of vaping products and now believe that the aerosol produced by these products is harmless to children.Paediatric health care providers need to help set the record straight and inform parents that e-cigarette vapour is not safe for children.Meanwhile, Dr Jonathan Winickoff, who led the study with Dr Drehmer, warned these attitudes are similar to those society had towards smoking decades ago - before the true dangers of tobacco were realised.He said: Frankly, its frightening. title: anaphylactic shock swallowing semen
story: The unidentied -year-old was rushed to hospital after she started vomiting, breaking out in hives and struggling to breathe.The patient, from Alicante, Spain, was admitted with suspected sensitised patients.We also recommend condom use during treatment with drugs that can induce hypersensitivity responses in partners.Almenara said that this was the first reported case of amoxicillin-induced anaphylaxis happening in a woman after having sexual contact with a man taking the drug.To our knowledge, this is the first case reported of a suspicion of amoxicillin-induced anaphylaxis in a woman after a sexual contact with a man who was taking the drug, we hypothesised an oral drug transfer through semen.Saying that, however, she also revealed that there had been a few reports of allergic reactions related to drugs being transferred through sexual intercourse.Reactions to the drug have happened via kissing before, but this is thought to be the first through oral sex.The bloke is thought to have taken the drug in question four hours before having sexual contact with the women.She was given a dose of adrenalin and steroids to combat her reaction and she was wants more people to be aware of how even trace elements in semen can cause issues.There are few cases reported of hypersensitivity reactions induced by drugs transported in semen but we have found some concern in sensitive patients about the possibility of transference of allergens via sexual intercourse.As clinicians, we consider that it is important to be aware of the existence of this Al Barrak, who shared the original audio of the incident claimed the mother hadnt simply left her baby at the terminal by itself.He instead claims the baby had been left with its sister who had boarded the wrong bus at the terminal and had missed the flight.When the mother realised the pair hadnt made the flight, she insisted the plane turn round, Mr Al Barrak claimed. Tens of thousands of people have now watched the video claiming to feature the air traffic control audio.Sun Online has contacted Saudia for comment.

title: ed stafford 60 days on the street documentary
story: The ex-Army captain, who was the first man to walk theof the Amazon, spent two months “homeless” in Manchester, Glasgow and London for a new documentary.But among the genuine misery and desperation, Ed was shocked to find rough sleepers earning up to £ a day and ate so much free food during the experiment that he GAINED weight.One person he encountered cheerfully admitted that being homeless was “easy”. Others fooled Ed with fake sob stories.The presenter, , said: “I met some fascinating people with extraordinarily touching and heartbreaking stories.“However, some turned out to not be true and some of the untruths became worse the more they unravelled. It was quite an emotional rollercoaster.”One of the characters he encounters is -year-old Geoff, who claims to have been evicted from his home after spending months in hospital following a suicide attempt.Ed, a married dad of one, is drawn to his determination sweeping the streets around hotels and restaurants in Manchester while politely approaching people for change “for a bed for the night”.Geoff tells him: “I’m homeless but I’m not a tramp. I’m not a junkie.”Ed believes his new friend has “fallen through the cracks” and forms a bond with the young man, believing the pair could have been friends in another le.Geoff says: “I’d love to pay taxes. I’d love to have a house. That’s just not how it is for me.”But when his persistent “grafting” results in more than £ in just half an hour, plus another tenner shortly afterwards, Ed learns the money is not going towards a hostel — but hard drugs.Later preparing a potentially lethal “snowball” mixture of heroin and crack cocaine, Geoff justies his choice by claiming he buys drugs only once or twice a month.Having first tried heroin at , he adds: “I can’t afford to go to the pub and spend £, £ on beers, things that normal people do.“I can afford this. Whatever it is that I need to do to make my le bearable, then that’s what I’m going to do.”Unable to hide his disappointment, Ed concedes he has been “naive” to fall for Geoff’s self-pitying fabrication.At the start of the Channel  three-parter — called  Days On The Streets — Ed scavenges in bins for food and ends up chewing someone’s ’s old gum, found in a discarded salad box.He assumes le on the streets will leave him a bag of bones but is very much mistaken.In Glasgow he meets one homeless man who moans about getting TOO MUCH food.Ed said: “I witnessed  volunteers handing out food one night, and there were only two rough sleepers there. I even met one man who complained the public ‘overfeed’ him.”Ed gained lbs sleeping rough, thanks to the burgers and sandwiches given to him by the public.A blood test later showed he was at risk of heart diseasehe continued on such a high-fat diet.He said: “I was shocked by the amount of food available. I thought I was going to lose loads of weight and it was going to be harder to physically survive but there was an abundance of people wanting to help in all three cities.”Filming on his own phone and trailed by an unobtrusive camera crew, Ed met beggars earning hundreds of pounds in an evening, far outdoing taxpayers on minimum-wage jobs.A man called Mark tells him: “If I don’t make £ tonight, I’ll be gutted. I’m good at my f***ing job.”Looking back, the presenter said: “Begging seemed to be more lucrative than I ever imagined. It was common in London for people to make £ or £ in an evening, which is more than the average person earns in work.”Ed said he assumed “no one would want to be on the streetsthey had a choice” but found some of them would rather beg as it is easier than “navigating the benefits system”.For all the Geoffs and Marks sleeping rough on our streets, the plight and torment of others Ed meets is real.Dina, a mum of six, invites the presenter to spend a night in her temporary shelter in Piccadilly Gardens, Manchester, where she sleeps on two layers of cardboard, a sleeping bag and duvet.She tells of her previous le as a model for MS and Debenhams, and how she worked as an extra on Coronation Street.At , she was given a choice of whether to live with her strict dad, who was moving to Bristol, or with her drug-addicted mum. She chose the latter.Having spent two years on the street, she knows le could have turned out dferently for her.Dina, whose kids live with their father, says: “If I was pushed in the way a child should be pushed, in the right direction, I wouldn’t be sat here today. I would have made something of my le.”She sees her children but, crying, adds: “I can’t bring my kids here. If I was an asylum seeker, I’d have a house. This is my country, I was born here.”Dina is seen in the documentary acting in a motherly, protective way towards another female rough sleeper and tells a homeless man who asks her about drugs: “I don’t smoke it, you know I don’t.”The heartbroken mum chose the spot near a -hour Burger King because of its relative safety — but Ed flees when a bloody fight between some men breaks out nearby.When he s later, to find no trace of Dina’s shelter, he is told it was removed by waste collectors.Dina was not there to tell them it was her bed.During his relatively brief taste of sleeping rough, he kips in a doorway that is more like a public toilet and hears stories of homeless people being urinated on as they sleep.Some have had their sleeping bags slashed or set alight.Despite waking one morning to find his own bag had been soaked by a street cleaner, and being forced to wash himself with water from a toilet after a week without showering, Ed conceded even he could see how people were drawn into a le without rules.He said: “Sitting up against a wall, observing people, not having to follow any rules, it’s kind of what I do now. People talk about getting slightly addicted to the freedom, to the outdoor living on the streets.“You can do whatever you like when you like. You have got the fresh air, the social interaction with other homeless people. You get used to it.”Ed said the two months he spent on the streets were “surprising and shocking on almost every level” and added: “Some things were easier than I expected, such as finding food.“It turns out that there’s plenty of food on the streets for rough sleepers, especially in London.”Despite there being “a real sense of community” among some of the homeless people he met, Ed came away feeling “quite cynical” — although emphasised that behind each rough sleeper is a tragedy.He said: “I wouldn’t give directly to homeless people any more, sadly. I think there is plenty of food available for them, and so a lot of any cash they get is spent on drugs and alcohol.“I don’t believe the solution is cash handouts but I do believe they need a great deal more support and help than they are currently getting, to escape their situation.“I worry that the public enables their lestyle to some degree, with all their generosity.” Days On The Streets is on C on Thursday at pm.A Salvation Army spokesman said: “We applaud the generosity of the public in wanting to help people directly, but we recognise that providing cash can trap people in the endless cycle of homelessness and rough sleeping.  Many homelessness charities, including ours, focus on looking at the root causes of homelessness. Donating can help us with our work.”Cemal Ezel, CEO of Change Please, an organisation that trains homeless people as coffee baristas, said: “There needs to be a balance. If it’s a freezing cold night and by donating a few pounds that person can get into a hostel, it may save their le. However, on the whole not every night is freezing so some people use cash donations as an enabler. We try to help people through giving them a job and working their way out of the problem. We found  per cent of homeless people can work and want to.”Paul Noblet, head of public affairs for youth homelessness charity Centrepoint, said: “The decision as to whether to give homeless people money, food or other items should be a matter of personal choice.  If a young person is sleeping rough, the priority must be to get them into safe accommodation.”Stephen Robertson, CEO of The Big Issue Foundation, said: “Rough sleeping and begging are separate issues.  It’s reasonable to recognise that there seems to be, from anecdotal data, a growth in beggars and that leads to a moral and humanitarian question.  Ultimately, the answer lies with the inidual.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dominic raab theresa may prime minister run
story: Askedhe’d like to be Prime Minister after making a major speech on social mobility, the senior Tory Brexiteer said: “Never say never.”It heightened speculation that he will throw his hat into the ring when Mrs May stands down.And it comes amid a rapidly-rising belief among Tory MPs that the PM will be forced out within weeks.In his speech to Tory think tank Onward Mr Raab made a highly-personalised speech - telling how his Jewish refugee father battled to get him into a grammar school, how he reads the Gruffalo kids book to his two sons and boasting about his karate skills.He also laid out radical new policies to tackle inequality and halt Britain’s decline in social mobility.In a sign of the detailed planning he is already putting into a future leadership challenge he called for radical new policies such as paying high-performing teachers bumper salaries to teach in Britain’s roughest schools.He said the policy should be a priority, saying: “If there’s one change I’d like to see, having sat on the Education Select Committee between  and , it’s to pay teachers more for teaching in our tougher schools.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new eye test can spots the signs of alzheimers before symptoms appear
story: The technique has shown that webs of blood vessels in the retina are sparser in patients with the disease.It raises the prospect of opticians being able to check for brain health while updating prescriptions for glasses.The imaging technique enables doctors to see blood ­vessels smaller than the width of a human hair in high resolution.Scientists used it to compare the retinas of Alzheimer’s patients with those of people with mild cognitive impairment and others with normal brains.Researcher Dr Sharon Fekrat said: “It is possible that changes in blood vessel density . . . mirror what’s going on in the tiny blood vessels in the brain.“If we can detect these blood vessel changes in the retina before any changes in cognition, that would be a game changer.”She added: “Early diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease is a huge unmet need. It’s not possible for current techniques like a brain scan to screen the number of patients with this disease.”Dr Fekrat, of Duke University Medical Centre in North Carolina, said the eventual goal would be to use the technology to detect Alzheimer’s before symptoms appear — and to monitor changes in people taking part in trials of new treatments.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keep corbyn out more important than brexit
story: The hard-left extremists running ­Labour would inflict more real harm on Britain in weeks than even the most deranged Brexit scaremongers could imagine.Which is why blood-curdling threats from wannabe Tory martyrs to bring down their own Governmentthey don’t get their way are so insane.Both wings need to get a grip. But Remainers, like Nick Boles and Amber Rudd, also need to wake up to how their party has changed. It is not the Cameron outfit of three years ago. Brexit has changed it, for the time being at least.The Tories are polling a healthy  per cent only because of Leave voters. They are the Leave party. No one knows what Labour is — that’s partly why its ratings are in freefall.So it will be fatal to the Toriesthey betray .million voters by failing to secure Brexit on or around March  — and preside over a delay long enough to enable Boles’s unsustainable Norway- Plus sham, or even a new referendum.In a snap election millions of Leavers or natural Tories would never vote for Corbyn. Instead they would stay at home or maybe opt for Nigel Farage’s new party once it emerges.  Either will annihilate the Tories and put Corbyn in power.Theresa May’s Brexit deal is not as good as the Government claims, nor quite as bad as its detractors believe. Most Leavers vastly prefer No Deal and fair enough. We just do not believe they will ever get it. Remainers will do anything to prevent it.Mrs May’s deal gets Brexit over the line, as Michael Gove argues.  It avoids a far, far softer one.  It kills off a second referendum. And the future is then up for grabs.We greatly admire Tory backbenchers who have stuck to the Brexit promises on which they were elected. Buttoday they still cannot swallow their pride, hold their noses and back this deal, we fear the consequences.Their party may well pay a terrible price — and the country with it.THE best way to prevent morons invading football pitches and punching players is to make them a hate figure in the stands.Some idiots at Birmingham City cheered and clapped Paul Mitchell as he was escorted away after his sickening assault on Villa’s Jack Grealish. That’s exactly what he wanted.Buta club is docked points, or ordered to play its next half-dozen home games behind closed doors, fans won’t be laughing any longer.The next thug tempted to pull such a stunt would know they risk being vilied by every fan at the club.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jesus statue lake michigan first viewing years
story: The ft statue of Christ on the cross - the only such monument placed under fresh water in the world - is around  yards from the shore at Petoskey, Michigan.Hundreds headed to the town, near the US-Canada border, on Saturday to gaze at the stunning relic through a hole carved through ft of dense ice.The tragic story behind the lb marble statue - which is placed ft under in the murky depths of the Great Lake - dates all the way back to .It was then that it was bought following a tragic farming accident in the nearby town of Bad Axe that left a -year-old boy dead, according to Inside Edition.His grieving family purchased it from craftsmen in Italy for £, - which in todays money would be worth , .But they refused to keep it after the cross was damaged during shipment across the Atlantic.The stunning statue then made its way into the hands of a local ing club following an insurance sale in .Members then gained permission to lower it into the lake as a tribute to a er who had recently lost his le in nearby Torch Lake.It has since gone on to become a touching symbol of remembrance to all those who have lost their lives at sea.This weekends viewing saw  people take to the ice to look at the statue and pay their respects, according to WPBN.Some ventured from as far as Texas and Alaska to brave the cold and view the crucix.It is the first public viewing of the statue from the surface since  - the last time weather conditions allowed for people to walk out onto the ice.The statue is expected to last under water for a total of  years before erosion sets in.

title: night time loo visits sleep
story: Research reveals around . million working-age adults in the UK suffer from nocturia, needing to pee at least twice nightly.Experts estimate the impact on their health means they do seven days less work annually than unaffected Brits.The main triggers for the bladder condition include ageing, hormonal changes and prostate issues.Overall,  per cent of Brits are affected.The NHS recommends affected adults should drink less before bedtime and ditch caffeine.But medics said their findings were a “wake-up” call – and called on GPs and bosses to do more to help sufferers.Lead researcher Marco Hafner, from RAND Europe, said : “Doctors and health practitioners often overlook nocturia as a potential health problem associated with sleep loss, and patients can delay reporting the condition until it becomes unbearable and substantially affects their wellbeing.“Given the substantial economic implications of untreated nocturia, this should be a ‘wake-up’ call …of the importance of identying and treating nocturia.”Brits who have to wake up nightly to pee also suffer from lower le satisfaction and work engagement.The study used workplace survey data collected by Vitality UK.Many cases of nocturia are caused by an enlarged prostate pushing pressing into the bladder and blocking the urethra, the vessel through which it empties.Earlier research found a shot of booze up the bum could help the two millions affected fellas get a better night’s sleep.The jab helped to shrink enlarged prostates by a third — slashing the need for night-time loo visits by half.Professor Helen Stokes-Lampard, Chair of the Royal College of GPs, said: “Getting a good night’s sleep is one of the more important things we can do for our overall health and wellbeing – it goes without saying that without a decent amount of sleep, people will be less productive and more lethargic whilst they are awake.“Nocturia – having to get up frequently during the night to pass urine – can occur for a number of reasons.Maintaining a healthy weight, avoiding or reducing alcohol and caffeine intake and keeping fit can help prevent or delay onset of the causes of the condition.Several non-surgical interventions can also help manage symptoms. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman sawed off hand make insurance claim
story: The -year-old enlisted the help of her family in an apparent injury claim fraud, according to detectives in Slovenia.She was rushed to hospital in the capital Ljubljana claiming that she was the victim of a horric accident while cutting branches.But the woman left the severed hand at home in a deliberate attempt to ensure the injury was permanent, cops claim.She and a relative have been arrested and each face up to eight years in prisonconvicted, BBC News reports.They allegedly took out an insurance policy in recent weeks and had stood to gain around €, .The money would have been paid out in monthly instalments worth €,under their policy.Two other family members had been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the alleged fraud earlier this year but were later released.The severed hand was recovered by authorities in time for medics to sew it back on, officials say.

title: brexit deal backbenchers plea theresa may
story: A text went to Ministers on Sunday with a list of Tory MPs that whips believe could still shoot down Theresa May’s agreement.Insiders said the list appeared “desperate” given it included arch Brexiteer Steve Baker – the self-styled shop steward of the European Research Group and a fierce critic of the PM’s deal.One source said: “His name raised a few eyebrows. I’m not sure what any Cabinet Minister would say would help that much.”Some  Tories voted against the PM’s deal in January.But since Theresa May’s crushing defeat big name backbenchers such as Rob Halfon and Nigel Evans have indicated they will now back her to ‘deliver’ Brexit.One arch Brexiteer on Monday night said Theresa May was the only one who would be able to change their minds – by wringing fresh concessions out of Brussels.He said: “The trouble is there aren’t really people in Cabinet who have much clout left with us. Everyone who had much about them has left.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal house of commons meaningful vote theresa may
story: The PM won last-minute tweaks to the Irish backstop plan which she says will stop Britain being tied to the EU.But its still not clear whether or not the fix will be enough to convince rebel Brexiteers they should support her in tonights crunch vote.This evening the House of Commons will vote for a second time on whether or not to approve Mrs Mays deal.If she wins, Britain will be on track to leave the EU with a deal in  days time.Butthe deal falls, MPs are then likely to delay Brexit by up to three months in a further vote scheduled for later this week.Senior Brexiteers such as Jacob Rees-Mogg and Iain Duncan Smith warned the jury is still out and refused to say how they will vote tonight.But the pound soared by  per cent overnight as hopes rose that the backstop agreement would help the deal get over the line.Mrs May last night jetted to Strasbourg for last-ditch talks with top Eurocrats Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier.She secured a three-part deal which is designed to ensure Britain can never be trapped in the backstop with no means of escape.Mr Juncker warned the EU will not reopen talksthe deal falls in todays vote - saying: There will be no third chance.This morning Government legal chief Geoffrey Cox is expected to declare that the changes are legally binding - a key demand from Tory Brexiteers.Lawyers from the hardline European Research Group are today poring over the fix to decide whether they can back the PM.Ex-Tory leader Mr Duncan Smith said he would wait for the legal eagles to have their say before he chooses how to vote.He told the BBC: Clearly the statements made by the Government suggest that there has been change.Mr Duncan Smith suggested Mrs May should delay the meaningful vote to later this week so MPs have longer to weigh up the details.ERG boss Jacob Rees-Mogg admitted the changes were unquestionably a step in the right direction but added: Well have to see.He suggested he would follow the lead of the DUP, whose MPs are still examining the revised text.Fellow Brexiteer Nadine Dorries said: I am really hopeful that when the text has been scrutinised that it may just take us over the line.And David Davis suggested the tweaked deal is just about acceptable as long as Mr Cox signs off on it.He told talkRADIO: This is by no means what I would have liked but it will deliver Brexit.But senior backbencher Damian Collins said he would still vote against the deal tonight, saying: Nothing has really changed since last November.And hardliner Christopher Chope said the changes to the deal were a million miles away from what was needed to win his support.Remainers also hit out at the PM - showing that evenMrs May does win over dozens of Brexiteers the vote could still be tight.The PM was in negotiations with EU bosses until almost midnight on trying to seal a way out of the backstop.The two sides managed to agree a series of fixes which are designed to ensure that Britain doesnt get tied to the European customs union indefinitely.Britain and the EU published three key documents last night - one adds legal weight to the EUs promise that the backstop is temporary, and another is a pledge to work on hi-tech solutions which will keep the Irish border open without relying on the backstop.The third and most controversial fix is a unilateral statement by the UK, which states Britain has the right to quit the backstop without the EUs say-sotrade talks break down in future.At a joint press conference in Strasbourg late last night, Mrs May said: Now is the time to come together, to back this improved Brexit deal, and to deliver on the instruction of the British people.EU boss Mr Juncker said there will be no third chance to get more from the bloc and warned: It is this deal or Brexit might not happen at all.Tonight MPs will vote for the second time on whether to back the withdrawal agreement hammered out last year by Mrs May and the EU.In January they voted it down by a historic margin of  votes - meaning the PM must win over more than  rebels from the Tories, DUP and Labour in order to get the deal through tonight.She has promised thatthe deal fails again, MPs will have the right to choose between a No Deal Brexit on March , or delaying Brexit entirely by up to three months.Opposition parties have tabled a number of amendments to tonights vote which are designed to move Britain closer to a second EU referendum.But without the support of Labour, none of the motions are likely to pass.

title: brexit 5 fast facts you
story: NewsBrexit:  fast facts you need to know this morning with  days to goToday is D-Day. MPs will vote from pm on Theresa Mays Brexit deal after an th-hour dash to Strasbourg - and the result will decide our futureShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video theresa-faces-press-after-crunch-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts D-Day for Theresa Mays Brexit deal. MPs will hold their meaningful vote at pm on the -page pact she reached with the EU. Two months after her deal fell by a record defeat, and just  days before were supposed to leave, Mrs May will give Parliament a chance to have the final say. Last night she made a frenzied final dash to Strasbourg where she came up with a final offer.But she still faces defeat after several Tories and Labour rejected it. That would lead to a vote on No Deal Brexit tomorrow night followed by a vote on delaying Brexit on Thursday.The Commons chamber was packed past pm last night as MPs traded angry recriminations over the last-minute deal. Here are the five quick things you need to know as you wake up and go to work.  Theresa May last night claimed she had won legally binding changes to her plans after MPs demanded a change to the Irish border backstop.The backstop is an insurance clause that would keep the UK in EU customs rules from ,there is no agreement to keep the Irish border open. MPs feared the EU could use the clause to trap the UK in the backstop, holding the country to ransom in trade talks. So the UK and EU agreed a “joint interpretative instrument” to -page deal that, Mrs May claims, would provide a mechanism for the UK to quit the backstopthe EU is showing bad faith. It will give a key role to an arbitration  - who will hear appealsthe UK feels the EU is trying to keep it in the Northern Irish backstop against its will. Separately the new deal commits the parties to coming up with alternative arrangements by December .  In January Theresa May vowed to win “not a further exchange of letters, but a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.” She hasnt done that. The documents she has published are in addition to the -page agreement. They dont change its contents. Theresa May also promised to seek either a time limit, a unilateral exit mechanism, or alternative arrangements to the backstop. She hasnt done that. There is no time limit, and alternative arrangements are a future hope rather than being in place now. As for a unilateral exit mechanism... she may claim she has got it, but MPs will say dferent. It only worksthe UK can prove the EU is trying to trap us in the backstop against our will. And thats very subjective. Even Mrs Mays own statement to Parliament today admits her new deal “reduces the risk of being held in the backstop. It doesnt eliminate it. Labours Keir Starmer says its basically the same deal. . MPs look like theyll still vote against  While Remainers branded it a fig leaf, some Tories wafted over to back the Prime Ministers deal overnight. But thats nowhere near the  people she needs to change their votes from no to yes to pass it. And the DUP, whose votes are crucial, said they would judge the PM by her promises in January - which she hasnt kept . Labours Keir Starmer said it was a pile of broken promises. Remain-backing former attorney general Dominic Grieve told the BBC: “It doesn’t allow the UK the right to terminate the backstop at a time of its own choosing. Ultimately I dont think this document thats been produced makes any signicant dference. Brexiteer Tory ringleader Steve Baker said: I think this falls very far short of what the government whipped us to vote for. And his right-wing comrade Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was “unquestionably a step in the right direction,” but would not commit his vote. Even Iain Duncan Smith, one of the more hopeful-sounding Brexiteers, urged the PM not to rush things through and said she should delay the vote by  hours.  Before .am today, Attorney General Geoffrey Cox will publish his legal advice on the Brexit deal. MPs will scan his text keenly to seeit agrees the deal meets with promises by the Prime Minister. If he does, it will give many Tories political cover to back the deal. But even then, it may not be enough for Theresa May to win. Hard Brexiteers fume that Mr Cox was also involved in negotiating the deal - so hes marking his own homework. Labour are demanding he make a separate House of Commons statement at .pm, before the main debate on the Brexit deal kicks off this afternoon.. Oh, meanwhile, the City is planning a Brexit war room The Financial Conduct Authority has plans in place for a financial war room to take action in the event of a no-deal Brexit. It will oversee the necessary IT changes to keep Britains banking sector operationwe crash out without a deal. An FCA spokesman said: As part of our planning for all scenarios we have put in place contingency measures in the event of a hard Brexit. We will have teams in place throughout the weekend of exit to monitor the situation and respond as needed, working closely with the Treasury and the Bank of England.

title: brexit keir starmer savages theresa
story: NewsBrexit: Keir Starmer savages Theresa Mays new deal in fiery Commons statementLabours Shadow Brexit Secretary swept into full lawyer mode for a damning statement shooting down the Prime Ministers new dealShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video watch-kier-starmers-response-commons-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabours Keir Starmer tonight savaged Theresa Mays Brexit deal in a fiery House of Commons statement. The former Director of Public Prosecutions swept into full lawyer mode as he held aloft hundreds of pages of documents in a furious attack. He spoke after Theresa May jetted to Strasbourg for a last-ditch deal with the EU to persuade MPs to vote for her Brexit deal tomorrow night. Her deputy, David Lidington, told MPs the government had secured legally-binding changes that strengthen and improve the -page Brexit deal. He said a new joint instrument will prevent the EU trapping the UK in the Northern Ireland backstop - a clause that would extend EU customs rules over the UK - indefinitely.   And there will be a joint statement supplementing the future political declaration on trade setting out a negotiating track for changes to the Irish backstop. But Mr Lidington prompted shouts of uproar when he said MPs must now back the deal... to avoid a crisis. Jeremy Corbyn insisted that her negotiations had failed and called on MPs to reject the deal. And Sir Keir shot down Mr Lidingtons argument by saying Theresa May had promised to change the Brexit deal itself - and achieved no such thing.  Waving a fat wad of legal papers, Labours Shadow Brexit Secretary asked: Is a single word of the Withdrawal Agreement dferent now to the document that was agreed on November   He added: It sounds again asnothing has changed. Andthat is right, the Prime minister is left with a pile of broken promises. Its as much a matter of trust as substance. Sir Keir branded the situation absurd and made a cruel joke at the Cabinet Office ministers expense.  I don’t complain for not having advance notice of his statement, he told MPs. I’m not sure HES got advance notice. Sir Keir said MPs will be disappointed but not surprised. He said Labour would examine the plans, but boasting of signicant change when just repeating a January statement is not going to take anyone very far. Theresa May, speaking in Strasbourg, said the deal would honour the referendum result and is good for both the UK and the EU. She said she had secured legally binding changes to the Irish backstop.  But Labour MPs lined up to savage the new arrangement. Wes Streeting tweeted: Sat in the Chamber genuinely stunned by the futility and incompetence of the Government’s statement. We’re days away from exit. This is just smoke and mirrors. Labour MP Tracy Brabin added: Late night statement and still no wiser. He’s saying words but none seem to make sense. The new letter agreement isn’t part of the withdrawal agreement we will be voting on tomorrow.

title: brexit what changes theresa mays
story: NewsBrexit: What do the changes to Theresa Mays EU deal actually mean Last night the government announced that it had secured a number of legally binding agreementsShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video watch-theresa-mays-speech-full-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May claims shes secured legally binding agreements to go to with the Brexit withdrawal agreement. Shell be hoping that shes convinced the EU to enough changes to the Northern Irish backstop that will allow her Eurosceptic MPs to back it. The new version will be put to a meaningful vote in the House of Commons tomorrow. But will it be enough to swing her party - and the rest of Parliament - behind her deal  Heres what it all means and what happens next. Whats the big sticking point   The biggest sticking point is the Northern Ireland backstop. Eurosceptics fear that the insurance policy against a hard border in Ireland, as written, could keep the UK trapped in a partial union with Europe permanently. Crucially, Attorney General Geoffrey Coxs legal advice on the last version of the deal said it would not allow the UK to leave the backstop unilaterally. Theresa May tried to get either a time limit, a unilateral exit mechanism, or alternative arrangements to replace the backstop. Shes definitely not got the first thing she might claim she has the last thing, but its not available yet. She may claim shes secured the middle one but it all still looks a little fuzzy.  Three things:A legally-binding joint instrument which reflects a commitment to replace the backstop with alternative arrangements by December . Lidington says this would prevent the EU trying to trap the UK in the backstop deliberately. A joint statement to go alongside the political declaration, which Lidington says seeks to enhance and expedite the process of bringing the future relationship into force. A unilateral declaration on the temporary nature of the backstop, which will sit alongside the Withdrawal Agreement. This says that it is the UKs understanding thatthe EU doesnt keep up its end of the bargain in the future relationship negotiations, Britain can pull out of the backstop on its own. Its unclearthis will be enough to satisfy Geoffrey Cox that the UK can leave unilaterally. Not technically, no. The Withdrawal Agreement will go ahead exactly as it was before. These three things are new documents which will go alongside the existing agreements. In a tweet, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said: Our agreement provides meaningful clarications and legal guarantees to the Withdrawal Agreement and backstop. And hes again warned that this is the EUs best and final offer: The choice is clear, he wrote. It is this deal, or Brexit may not happen at all. Lets bring the UKs withdrawal to an orderly end. We owe it to history.   Is Brussels up for an extension  It seems so - but the detail of this could be super important. Jean-Claude Juncker has said in very clear terms thatthe UK is going to leave, it has to do so before the European Elections, which take place on - May. If the United Kingdom has not left the European Union by then,he wrote, it will be legally required to hold these elections, in line with the rights and obligations of all Member states as set out in the treaties. So up for an extension, but only a short one. Will it be enough to get the deal through   It’s too early to know for sure, but the Prime Minister’s prospects of completely undoing last time’s -vote defeat look bleak. While Labour MPs blasted the statement as “smoke and mirrors”, some Tories sounded a lot more hopeful, giving good odds we won’t see the record defeat we did in January. But the real people to convince were the DUP - since where their  Northern Irish Unionist MPs go, many Tory Brexiteers will follow. And tonight the DUP issued a statement to Sky News that could be the final nail in the deal for the PM. The DUP didn’t rule out backing the deal. But crucially, the party said it would measure the new plan against “the commitments made by the Prime Minister on  January.”  Those commitments included to win “not a further exchange of letters, but a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.” It is pretty obvious the Prime Minister has not achieved that. Two key elements will decide the Prime Minister’s fate - the full legal text, which was published very late on Monday, and legal advice by the Attorney General Geoffrey Cox. If Mr Cox’s own legal advice is pessimistic about the deal, he cannot hope to persuade enough Tories to back it.

title: officials accused cover up over
story: NewsOfficials accused of cover up over cost of Boris Johnsons Afghanistan tripEXCLUSIVE: Officials blamed an IT issue after details of the embarrassing trip were slipped out to a member of the public while journalists responses were delayedShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR NewsBoris Johnson ing from his trip to Kabul "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOfficials have been accused of trying to “cover up” the cost of Boris Johnson’s trip to Afghanistan the day of a controversial vote. The former foreign secretary blew more than pound, of taxpayer’s cash on a visit to Kabul, which allowed him to miss a crunch vote on Heathrow expansion in June last year. Officials blamed an “IT issue” after details of the embarrassing trip were slipped out to a member of the public, while journalists’ requests were delayed. And following a six month battle, the Foreign Office was forced to admit they had internally identied requests from “known journalists”, breaking Freedom of Informationrules. And officials refused to reveal details of the ‘IT issue’ due to “national security” concerns. FOI expert Matt Burgess said: “Its outrageous, the law is meant to be applicant and motive blind. “This seems like a cover-up where the government is trying to hide information from journalists because they want an easier ride.”   He added: “Everyone should get the same responses to FOI requests, no matter who they are.” Shameless Mr Johnson travelled to Kabul on an last-minute visit on the same day he would have been forced to vote in favour of Heathrow expansion to keep his job. Mr Johnson once claimed he would lie down in front of the bulldozers to stop the poundbn plan for a third runway. Details of the trip were quietly disclosed to a member of the public in response to an FOI request. But they were not revealed to the Mirror and at least one other publication until a complaint was lodged, days later. The Foreign Office last night denied that it had deliberately held back the information from the media, or treated members of the press dferently to members of the public. But in emails dealing with the request, one official told colleagues: “I’m happy to clear these but can you provide a list of who they are from ”   Another email confirmed an official had “provided details of any known journalists.” The Information Commissioner’s guidance bans public bodies from dferentiating journalists from members of the public when dealing with FOI requests. It’s understood the Foreign Office did suffer an IT problem on the day the data was originally disclosed. But officials have been unable to explain why it affected some applicants and not others. And the department refused to make details of the IT problem public, saying it would be a threat to national security. A further request, for details of how the case had been managed by the Foreign Office, was delayed six time beyond its  working day time limit. Eventually the department revealed some of the information a full  working days late, without providing any explanation.
