story: NewsUniversal Credit: Around , claimants moved to new regime without full supportSome .million people are now on Universal Credit - and its Director General has revealed "roughly half" of those joining are existing claimants in the benefit systemShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video universal-credit-new-regime-move-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA DWP chief tonight appeared to suggest around , benefit claimants have been forced onto Universal Credit without transition cash. Neil Couling, UC Director General, told MPs roughly half of those joining the six-in-one system are existing benefit claimants whose circumstances have changed. As of January this year, .million people were on UC. Existing benefit claimants who are moved to UC will have a transition fund to ensure their income doesnt drop, in a trial that starts in Harrogate this July and only rolls out fully in . But these protections do not apply to people whose circumstances change.   MPs have heard this so-called natural migration is triggered by changes in circumstances as small as a relationship breakup or a childs fth birthday. Labour MP Neil Coyle said the move was having a terrible impact on many peoples lives. Work and Pensions Committee chairman Frank Field said: People moving over are stranded. They dont have enough money.  In a hearing of the committee today, Mr Coyle asked what message the new trial sent to those who have already moved. He told Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd: What are we, five years in  And youre beginning a new pilot to see how Universal Credit works  Independent Group MP Heidi Allen added: Its pushing people under the water.  Ms Rudd replied to the MPs: It has always been the case thatyou change your circumstances and need to apply for new benefit, you may find that the situation of the benefits that are being proposed have changed. But Ms Allen said it was a problem hitting people whod moved two yards down the road. Asked how many people had had a change of circumstances, Mr Couling told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee: “It is hard to give a precise estimate. Because obviously it depends on the number of changes of circumstances that occur in a period, and that itself could be determined by economic and other factors. “But roughly it’s about half and half of caseload growth is through a change in circumstance - and half is through a pure new claim to benefit. Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood said: “The government has always claimed that nobody will be worse off under Universal Credit, but we now know that half of all households who claim it are at risk of losing out as a result. “Universal Credit is being used as a vehicle for cuts and people who are being forced to move across from other benefits because of a change of circumstance receive no protection against loss of income. “Labour will stop the roll out of Universal Credit and deliver a social security system that supports any of us when we need it.”  Policy in Practice warned % of UC claimants who move through natural migration lose out by an average of pound a week compared to the old system. Meanwhile % are expected to gain by pound a week, the think tank told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee. Asked to respond to the suggestion , people had moved through natural migration, a DWP spokesperson said: “Only new claimants or people who have undergone a change in circumstances are currently being asked to apply for Universal Credit . Where someone’s circumstances change it’s right that we reassess their entitlement to ensure they’re receiving the right level of support.” Ms Rudd admitted the initial rollout of UC, and the wait for payments, did I believe contribute to the growth of food banks” but insisted reasons are “ied”, and since the period she was talking about there’s been “vast improvement”. Meanwhile, Amber Rudd told MPs the four-year freeze on most working-age benefits will stay until March , but she expected it will end after that. I have private conversations with the Chancellor, she said. And she revealed the DWP have drawn up plans to hire extra staff in a No Deal Brexit . The Work and Pensions Secretary told a committee of MPs: “We have been making preparations for no deal planning. “We are making sure thatthere is an economic downturn, we are prepared to hire additional people should there be fewer jobs available as a result of a no deal exit.” She also confirmed reports the government overall has been looking at the possibility of a “hardship fund”there is no deal.

title: voice mirror safety must come
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Safety must come first with flights - so we must investigateThe public will rightly be concerned that British airlines are refusing to take Boeing  Max s out of service, after Sunday’s accident in Ethiopia and an earlier one off the coast of IndonesiaShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionPeople stand near collected debris at the crash site of Ethiopia Airlines near Bishoftu "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGrounding Boeing  Max s for urgent safety checks is sensible after two new planes crashed within five months of each other, killing hundreds of people. The public will rightly be concerned that British airlines are refusing to take them out of service, after Sunday’s accident in Ethiopia and an earlier one off the coast of Indonesia. Safety should be paramount in the aviation industry, which is why international air accident investigators are anxious to discoverthe two crashes were a grim coincidence or evidence of a more widespread problem. We are not prejudging the inquiry’s outcome.   But when Ethiopia, Indonesia and China are among the nations grounding the jets, surely erring on the side of caution is the right choice. US manufacturer Boeing will have to co-operate fully and allow its performance records to be examined. It is better to be safe than sorry when it comes to people’s lives. Brexit caution Last throws of the dice are rarely as theatrical as Theresa May’s dash to Strasbourg for Brexit talks last night. She’s desperately searching for a solution that forces hardline Tories to start backing her bad deal. But our country will pay the price. The truth is that May’s poundbillion EU orce would be an expensive, avoidable disaster. MPs should hold their nerve, refuse to be panicked, reject her poor offering and vote for extra time to find an answer that is best for Britain.  A growing chorus of Tories are demanding that she quit, but May is prioritising her own position over the national interest. And that isn’t leadership – that’s putting herself first. Halt kne sales Stopping the sale of terrying “Rambo” knives – popular among some gang members – is a small but signicant step towards reducing street violence. We have consistently argued that there’s no single, simple answer to halting stabbings, but fewer weapons is surely part of the solution.

title: brit couple face 140k singapore
story: NewsBrit couple face £k Singapore hospital bill after mum suddenly gives birth earlyChloe Wilkinsons travel insurance did not cover the unexpected birth of little baby Lorcan during a stopover in SingaporeShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  MAR NewsThe couple were planning to tell their parents about the pregnancy once home - but little Lorcan wasnt waiting"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British couple stranded in Singapore face a poundk hospital bill after their baby was born premature at  weeks. Chloe Wilkinson, , and Patraic Walsh-Kavanagh, , were travelling back to the UK to tell their parents about the surprise pregnancy. But Chloe went into labour during a stopover in Singapore and gave birth to their son Lorcan, who weighed just .lbs. He is currently in intensive care and will have to stay in hospital for at least the next three months.    Chloe and Patraic took out travel insurance ahead of their once-in-a-letime trip, which began in December . But the policy didnt cover the unexpected pregnancy. Teaching assistant Chloe said: Lorcan’s been fighting with all his might and we are bursting with pride at the strength he is showing so far. “However, we are on our own, a  hour flight away from our family and friends, and it has been a very dficult start to parenthood whilst Lorcan remains in hospital.    Its still such a huge shock to us both that hes here but were doing everything we possibly can to ensure we all get back to the UK. Patraic added: We were in a complete state of shock and fear completely took over as we were faced with a severely premature baby with potentially multiple health issues whilst being stuck in a country with no support. “On top of this I was handed an estimated bill of poundk [, SGD] assuming there will be no further complications with Chloe or the baby. Teaching assistant Chloe and Patraic left the UK in December  to go travelling around Asia.    They then found work together in Australia before discovering Chloe was pregnant last November. The couple, who wanted to tell their parents the news in person, began flying home last month. But during a two-day stopover in Singapore Chloe was rushed to hospital after experiencing bleeding and cramps. Doctors told her she had started dilating at just  weeks - meaning flying home was no longer an option. Patraic, from Nottingham, East Mids, said: All the doctors and nurses seemed very concerned.   After numerous tests it was found that she had an infection so she was started on antibiotics and medication to reduce contractions and prolong labour to give baby the best chance of survival. However, Chloe, from Lincoln, fell more seriously ill and medics decided they had to deliver Lorcan immediately. She said: I was absolutely terried because I knew it was too early. When my water broke the room was quickly filled with doctors, midwives and paediatricians As soon as he was delivered he went straight into an incubator where the paediatricians started to help him breathe and stabilise him before whisking him off to intensive care. Hes fighting and doing his best but we feel so helpless.    Lorcan is currently in intensive care while his parents are living in a shared flat near the hospital. Their lack of working visas means they are unable to seek employment to support themselves. So the couple are trying to raise as close to pound, on GoFundMe to help pay for Lorcans hospital bills. By Monday afternoon they had raised more than pound,. Chloe added: Were professional people who work hard but its obviously a huge sum and anything anyone can offer to help would be greatly appreciated. We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone at home and across the world for their continued love and support. The travel insurer has been approached for comment.Anyone wishing to help the couple can visit their Go Fund Me page

title: head teacher defends ban pupils
story: NewsHead teacher defends ban on pupils being given sweets on their BIRTHDAYSAmerican Chasey Crawford-Usher wasnt allowed sweets growing up and is alarmed by how much sugar British kids eatShareCommentsByHelena Kelly:,  MAR NewsOne Kent school is saying no to sugary sweet "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA head teacher insists she is not the fun police - despite banning children from bringing in sweets on their birthday.Chasey Crawford-Usher has also prohibited crisps and fruit juice from her school in Kent.The American-born teacher says she imposed the ban after being shocked by how much sugar British children were consuming. The self-confessed health fanatic insists the move is in the best interests of pupils.   She said: First of all, Im not the head teacher of all evil and saying no. Ive banned birthday sweets because they were becoming a huge problem in the school and mean the children were consuming processed sugar almost every day. Mrs Crawford-Usher, from New England, America, admits she wasnt allowed sweets growing up and claims her mother was a Whole Foods mum before it was trendy. She noted that children are provided with healthy and wholesome school dinners such as spaghetti bolognese, shepherds pie and roast dinners - all made with fresh ingredients.The strict head of Wateringbury Primary School also said desserts were on the table but they too were natural and unprocessed.  Despite the drastic measures, Mrs Crawford-Usher claimed students and parents have seldom complained. She said: People are angry about it for about a week and then it just becomes normal. I really havent had much of a backlash. Children can eat and drink whatever they want when they get home, I just want to provide them with healthier choices at school. The dental problems among schoolchildren now are awful and I want to do what I can to prevent it.   Its a terribly traumatic ordeal for a child to have their tooth extracted and its something I want to avoid. It comes after recent figures revealed ,  under-s needed tooth extractions last year. Public Health England estimated that youngsters were eating around eight more cubes of sugar per day than the recommended guidelines.However, Mrs Crawford-Ushers decision has come under fire on social media from Olympic race walker Tom Bosworth.He said: Again, common sense needs to be used here. Really what is happening to society to ban kids from having sweets on their birthday. - ban them every other dayyou like, but let a child be a child on their birthday though. The head hit back and said the Olympian had perhaps missed the point. She said: Yes, I think pupils should be able to eat sweets on their birthday buteach and every child brings them in to celebrate, the children would be eating them nearly every day. Also it puts an unfair pressure on parents to bring in sweets when perhaps they dont agree with them. Wateringbury CE Primary School is based near Maidstone, Kent.   Its mission statement reads: Our vision...to be an excellent primary school at the heart of the community where we inspire, excite and enable children to achieve. It was rated good in a  Ofsted report and Mrs Crawford-Usher said the obesity levels among pupils falls slightly below the national average. She has been head teacher of the school for eight years. And its not the first time the head teacher has cracked down on junk food.Last January Mrs Crawford-Usher banned the schools kids from eating crisps four days a week.  The school had previously banned sugary drinks like fizzy sodas and fruit juices too. Teachers are also encouraged to take pupils out of the classroom three times a week for a ten-minute run.Her drastic moves came after figures showed nearly one-in-five Year  pupils locally were classed as obese, with some areas of Kent leading the tables for older overweight primary school children.

story: NewsMadeleine McCann suspect seen carrying small girl is key to solving case, expert saysThe mystery man was spotted by an Irish family, the Smiths, on the night three-year-old Madeleine vanished in May ShareBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMadeleine was just three when she vanished in Portugal in May  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man seen carrying a small girl dressed in pyjamas on the night Madeleine McCann vanished is key to solving the case, an expert claims.The mystery man was spotted by an Irish family, the Smiths, who were holidaying in Portugal at the same time as the McCanns in May . The family would later claim they saw him carrying a girl, wearing pink and white pyjamas, down a quiet street around m from the beach. And US criminal profiler Pat Brown believes the sighting is the key in Madeleines case, which has yet to be solved more than a decade on. This is the number one issue about the whole case, and Ive stuck by this for years, and I stand by it today, she told  News in a podcast. Madeleine was just three when she vanished from an apartment in Praia da Luz, where she had been sleeping with her twin siblings.   At the time, her parents Kate and Gerry were dining with pals nearby.The reported sighting by the Smiths was at around pm on May , . The same night, a friend of Kate and Gerry also reportedly saw a dark-haired man carrying a child away from the direction of the apartment.But this sighting, by Jane Tanner, was reported to be  minutes before the Smiths one and was in a dferent location, the news site reports. Jane claimed she had gone for a walk when she saw, in the darkness and from some distance, a man carrying a child across the road ahead.“What makes the Smith sighting very interesting is that Jane Tanner is a friend, and the Smith sighting is a bunch of people that have no clue who the McCanns are, Pat, from Washington DC, says in the Maddie podcast.   These are not their friends. She adds: I believe the Smith sighting occurred. I believe they saw a man carrying a little girl down that road, which is towards the beach. E-fits of a suspect, based on evidence from holidaymaker Martin Smith and his family, were unveiled years after Madeleines disappearance.Meanwhile, an artist drew an impression of the so-called Tannerman - the man spotted by Jane, who was considered a suspect for years. Pats comments are made in the third episode of the podcast, which looks into the high-profile case and the two sightings that night.According to  News, the criminal profiler has studied the case in exhaustive detail, even flying out to visit Praia da Luz itself. Madeleine would now be , turning  in May this year.In November , Operation Grange, the Met Police investigation into her disappearance, was given a further pound, from the Home Office. This provided funding up to March  this year. The podcast is hosted by Australian journalist Mark Saunokonoko. A Netflix documentary about the case is set to be broadcast next month. Kate and Gerry earlier released a statement about the Netflix show. They said: We are aware that Netflix are planning to screen a documentary in March  about Madeleine’s disappearance. story: NewsPensioner, , caught with .million child abuse images jailed for  yearsGeoffrey Crossland, from Harrogate, North Yorkshire, also admitted storing prohibited firearms in a secret underground bunkerShareByHenry Clare:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSick Geoffrey Crossland has been jailed for more than  years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner who amassed one of Britains largest known collections of indecent images and stored guns in a secret bunker has been jailed. Geoffrey Crossland today admitted to storing prohibited firearms in an underground bunker at his home in Harrogate, North Yorkshire. When officers raided the sprawling Padside Green Farm property, they found guns hidden underneath it, along with ammunition. Police had been investigating the -year-old after he was found to have amassed more than . million indecent images. The horric pictures were described by the Crown Prosecution Service as one of the biggest known collections in England and Wales.  North Yorkshire Police said their seizure was the biggest in the county, and included , images in the most extreme category A. Appearing at York Crown Court earlier today, Crossland admitted  charges in relation to the possession of firearms and ammunition. He had previously pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images between January  and October . And this afternoon, the defendant was sentenced to  years and eight months behind bars by His Honour Judge Andrew Stubbs. Sentencing Crossland, the judge said: A search on your home led to the discovery of an enormous amount of indecent images of children.  In a locked box, devices and hard drives there was also a discovery of carefully stored images of many years dating back to . These were systematic searches, some of which found children between - being raped and others of young girls receiving a signicant amount of sexual abuse. Crosslands home was raided while he was holidaying abroad last year.He was arrested on histo Heathrow Airport in an operation conducted by police and the National Crime Agency . Stephen Wood, prosecuting, told the court: It [the bunker] was fitted with electrics and from there they recovered USBs, sim cards, external hard drives, laptops, computers, tablets, floppy disks and DVDs. Among the evidence there was a worrying document which had been created with login details so he [Crossland] couldnt forget which websites to access.  There was also websites on the documents listed with where he could access the best websites for indecent images of children and where he could share the information without being suspected. He even categorised the websites by the content and who had made them. Susannah Proctor, defending, said: The bunker at his home was made in  from storage containers which he applied for permission. He worked from his home at that time for his business creating manufactured electrical components. He possessed the firearms because he was an enthusiast and had been since he was  years old. This was also a hobby he shared with his father. Former businessman Crossland was jailed for five years for the possession of indecent images,  months for possessing moving images of a young girl, and six years for the illegal possession of firearms.  He was also issued with a ten-year Sexual Harm Prevention Order and placed on the sex offenders register for ten years. Detective Chief Inspector Graeme Wright, of North Yorkshire Police, was the senior investigating officer in the case. He said: This is without doubt the largest ever seizure of indecent images of children in the history of North Yorkshire Police. The investigation as a whole has been on a scale never seen before in our area regarding this type of offending. More than  digital devices were seized from an office area above the underground bunker complex on Crosslands premises. Each device had to undergo painstaking examination by North Yorkshire Polices Digital Forensic Unit supported by a team of specialist officers from the National Crime Agency.  There was also the recovery of the prohibited firearms and ammunition. We knew that Crossland had, legitimately, been an active member of shooting clubs over the years and he had acquired a large collection of firearms-related items and ammunition which he stored in the bunker. Nevertheless, everything had to be seized and carefully assessed to determine what was and what wasnt legally held. Marc Horsfall, of the National Crime Agency, said: A team of specially trained NCA officers spent several months working through Crosslands horric catalogue of abuse images to grade them in order of severity. Crossland and men like him are fuelling the actual contact abuse of children and the sickening distribution of those images. The NCA works with partners at home and abroad to catch child sex offenders and bring them to justice.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Storm Gareth ,-mile weather bomb to bring mph galesThe Met Office has issued severe weather warnings for most of the UK as the ,-mile wide "weather bomb" hitsShareCommentsByChris kitchingAlistair Grant:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video weather-warnings-place-storm-gareth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Dangerous Storm Gareth is set to bring potentially destructive and le-threatening weather conditions that threaten widespread travel chaos and power cuts to most of the UK. The ,-mile wide weather bomb has triggered severe weather warnings from the Met Office with gales up to mph and heavy rain expected for more than  hours once the storm makes landfall.A yellow warning for strong winds covers Northern Ireland, Wales, most of England and western parts of Scotland, while a rain warning has been issued for the North West of England, where more than two inches could fall. Storm Gareth brings a risk of damage to buildings, flying debris, large waves and flooding in addition to power cuts and travel chaos, forecasters said. Showers could be wintry over hills while northern and central parts could be hit by thunderstorms and hail as the country is battered by the massive and powerful storm.   The intense storm, caused by a deep area of low pressure, has been given a name to bring greater urgency and awareness to the Met Offices warnings. Forecasters have urged people to take precautions so they arent caught out by severe weather. The Met Office has issued three separate weather warnings for wind or rain before the worst of Storm Gareth hits. The first covers the North West of England, where more than two inchesof rain could fall over higher ground in Cumbria by pm on Tuesday, increasing the risk of flooding on already wet ground.  About .insis expected quite widely. The second warning, for wind, covers Northern Ireland from pm Tuesday to pm Wednesday. The Met Office said: A spell of strong northwesterly winds are expected across Northern Ireland for the evening travel period, continuing overnight and Wednesday morning. Gusts of up to mph are likely inland with a small chance of reaching mph for a time in squally showers.  Gusts of -mph are likely along northern coasts, perhaps up to mph for a time. Winds will steadily ease through Wednesday morning. Those strong winds will later extend into Wales, England and Scotland, where a yellow warning will be in place from pm on Tuesday until pm on Wednesday. The Met Office warned: A spell of strong northwesterly winds is expected to develop across southwest Scotland late on Tuesday evening then extend across much of England and Wales through Wednesday.  Gusts of up to -mph are likely inland and mph along western coasts. Winds will gradually ease during Wednesday afternoon. Almost two dozen flood alerts have been issued across northern England. In Wales, four have been issued around Snowdonia National Park and two in Brecon Beacons National Park. Scotland has issued six flood warnings and two flood alerts.  On Tuesday morning, winds were already gusting to mph at Mumbles Head in South Wales, and mph at both St Marys on the Isles of Scilly and the South Ulst Range in northwest Scotland. By .am almost two inchesof rain had fallen at Capel Curig in North Wales over the previous  hours, while Shap in Cumbria had recorded a similar amount . A yellow weather warning for rain is also in place in parts of northern England on Thursday and Friday. Drivers have been told to expect longer journey times, while air, rail and bus passengers could face delays or cancellations.  Temperatures will hit about C in some places, but it wont feel pleasant due to the wind and or rain. Gareth is slamming in the UK just days after severe winds, snow and rain caused disruption on Sunday. Why Storm Gareth  The Met Office and Met Eireann, the Irish weather service, produce a list of storm names just before the beginning of autumn every year. Its believed that people pay closer attention to severe weather warningsit is a named storm. Gareth was named by Met Eireann and is the third named storm this year after Erik in February and Freya earlier this month. Gareth has been dubbed a ,-mile wide weather bomb, or explosive cyclogenesis, when air pressure drops rapidly in a single day.  The rotation of a storm is increased, creating destructive weather conditions. Storms Ali and Bronagh hit in September last year, Callum in October and Deirdre in December. The next named storms will be Hannah, Idris and Jane. Met Office five-day weather forecastTuesdayHeavy rain across Wales and northern England, spreading southeastwards, with gusty winds. Brighter skies following from the north and later west, with heavy, blustery showers, wintry over northern hills. Turning very windy later, with severe gales in the northwest. Tuesday nightVery windy with severe gales in the north. Heavy and squally showers across northern and central parts with risk of hail of thunder. Drier in the south with clear spells.WednesdayCold and very windy with sunshine and showers, heavy in places with snow over northern hills. Showers will steadily ease but rain will reach the west later.Thursday to SaturdayUnsettled throughout with bouts of wind and rain, heaviest in the west. Some drier and brighter interludes are likely. Rather cold in the north, milder at times in the south. Snow on the way The Met Offices extended forecast is predicting further spells of rain and snow as spring nears. The forecast, for Saturday  March to Monday  March, says: Cloud and rain are expected to affect the south, and perhaps central parts, of the UK early on Saturday, and will clear with bright and showery weather extending countrywide by the days end. Showers may be heavy in the north and fall as a mixture of sleet or snow, especially on high ground.Any strong winds will ease through the day too. Lighter winds and cooler on Sunday. Then there are signals for an Atlantic-driven and unsettled theme through the following week. We are likely to see further spells of wind and rain, followed by drier, more showery periods. The wettest, windiest weather always most likely in the northwest. Towards the end of the outlook there may be a tendency for more settled conditions to affect southern areas. The first day of spring is Wednesday  March.

title: woman planned entire wedding bought
story: NewsWoman has planned entire wedding and bought dress - despite not having a groomA woman has planned out her entire wedding, from the venue to the shoes but theres one major thing shes missingShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR NewsTheresa Mahon has planned her entire wedding, despite being single "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa Mahon has already spent more than pound, on her dream wedding. Shes got the perfect dress all sorted, shes bought a sparkling tiara and she knows exactly what shade shade of pink her bridal bouquet is going to be.The only thing shes missing for her big day  Well, that would be the groom.The -year-old mum-of-three is single and hasnt dated anyone in three years, but that hasnt stopped her from spending the last year planning every single detail of her fairy tale Cinderella-themed wedding.  As part of this planning, Theresa, who lives in Dublin, knows the event will take place at a castle venue and Christina Perris A Thousand Years is going to be the song she and her husband have their first dance to - as shes been waiting for what feels like a thousand years to find the one.She also knows what food will be served on the day , what kind of shoes shes going to wearand that she wants to spend the honeymoon in Disneyland.And while some may think its odd to have so much planned without even being engaged, the mum disagrees, arguing that its sensible as there will be very little left to worry about when the time comes.  Her idea to plan the wedding was sparked when she and her partner broke up after six years of dating and having two kids together.The pair had discussed marriage, but sadly the relationship just didnt work out the way shed thought it would.Following the split, she decided she wouldnt let her lack of a prince charming stop her from getting on with her le and achieving her dream of getting married, so she started working out what she wanted. The mum admits that the wedding has become an obsession to her, but she is open to compromise when she finally meets the right man - though shes adamant the first dance song is not up for negotiation.  Theresa is also aware that some men may be put off by her grand plans, but shes hopeful that it wont put too many people off.Speaking on ITVs This Morning, she said: I can understand people are kinda gonna go oh God no, thats just too much too soon and I completely understand that.But Im not looking to marry someone within like the first six weeks of meeting them, like obviously you have to see how the relationship goes.While talking to Holly Willoughby, the mum also revealed her dream man would be a cheeky chap like Olly Murs, and she got a shock when he appeared on screen with a special message for her.Hi Theresa, its Olly here, Ive been hearing about your wedding day and its all planned and ready to go, he said. He continued: Im single, I hear that youre looking for the ideal man, youve said its me... right  He looked off screen and asked: Are we available that day  When the person said no, he replied that it was a shame.

title: mum whose lunch kept getting
story: NewsMum-to-be whose lunch kept getting stolen at work catches thief and has her firedDont mess with a hungry pregnant womanShareCommentsByBlathin De PaorZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsElizaconceived again VERY quickly "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It doesnt matteryoure a CEO or an intern, having your food nicked from the fridge is an occupational hazard wherever you work .If youre lucky, this will only happen on a handful of occasions during your working le. Youll fume, perhaps resort to passive-aggressive labels, maybe even send a scathing email, but youll get over it. Imagineit happened to you every day, though For one mum-to-be this is exactly what was happening to her.Every day she took in a delicious homemade lunch created for her by her chef husband.Every day it got pinched from the fridge at work, RSVP Live reports.  She even explained that her husband would happily make the thief lunch, for a small fee. But while other colleagues took her up on this, the thief persisted. Then cameras were installed in the kitchen. She told Reddit: I began labelling my food hoping that would deter the thief. It didnt. Eventually, I put a note on the fridge that said: Please stop taking my food. I am pregnant and breastfeeding and this is negatively affecting my health.  The thief was a middle-aged woman who doesnt seem to like me. She is making triple what I am making,not more. After a week of thisI had the IT guy send me a screen-grab of her stealing, one from each day. Lunch Thief was up for a promotion. She’s near the executive level, and once you get this high up, the interviews involve execs from headquarters flying down to meet up with the execs in our office to sit in on presentations from the interviewees. The mum-to-be then admitted that she pinned up a photo of the lunch thief stealing her food.   Sheturned back to look at the screen in horror. The execs at my office who knew my lunches were getting stolen were visibly pissed at her. As it turns out, one of the execs who’d come from headquarters was also pregnant, and the other one had a we who’d just had a baby. She was terminated. It sounds cutthroat, but the woman reveals she never wanted it to go this far.  I didnt want her to get fired, I just wanted her to stop. If theyd ever talked to me, I wouldnt have wanted to get her fired. Aside from seeing the picture in the interview, they never involved me further. Never even asked me to send them the picture evidence for their own record.

title: woman 31 severe allergic reaction
story: NewsWoman, , has severe allergic reaction after performing sex act on boyfriendDoctors in Alicante, Spain, have now warned oral sex can cause anaphylactic shockShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe woman became unwell after forming a sex act on her partner [file image] "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman suffered a le-threatening allergic reaction after performing oral sex on her partner. The -year-old vomited and struggled to breathe after swallowing her boyfriends semen. She was rushed to hospital in Alicante, Spain, where doctors suspected shed gone into anaphylactic shock. The woman revealed she had an allergy to penicillin but denied having taken the drug, or any unusual foods, before performing fellatio. But medics at Hospital General Universitari dAlacant found her -year-old boyfriend had taken amoxicillin-clavulanic acid – a form of penicillin – to treat an ear infection before their sexual encounter. Its believed the case is the first of its kind ever recorded. British Medical Journal Case has now used the case as a warning to others.   Susana Almenara, lead author of the report, has urged anyone with known drug allergies to be aware of the potential risk and ensure they use condoms.  We think that as clinicians it is important to be aware of this phenomenon so was to inform and prevent potentially serious reactions in sensitised patients. We also recommend condom use during treatment with drugs that can induce hypersensitivity responses in partners, she said. She added: This is the first case reported of a suspicion of amoxicillin-induced anaphylaxis in a woman after a sexual contact with a man who was taking the drug. The man, who also wasnt identied, took the medication four hours before having any sexual contact with the woman.   But his lover had to spend around one week recovering in hospital. She was given doses of adrenaline, steroids and salbutamol. Ms Almenara quoted figures from another study that showed around one in  penicillin treatments result in an anaphylactic shock. Writing in the journal, she added: We have detected some concern about this issue in consultations carried out by sensitive patients in internet forums. This concern on the part of patients is accompanied by a lack of scientic information around this question. Ms Almenara added even the smallest presence of an allergen, such as penicillin, in semen could lead to anaphylaxis.

title: world must prepare inevitable flu
story: NewsWorld must prepare for ‘inevitable’ flu pandemic, warns World Health OrganisationThe last flu pandemic was caused by the HN virus and caused between , and , deaths globallyShareCommentsByKate KellandSofia Petkar:,  MAR NewsThe World Health Organisation says the risks of a flu pandemic are high "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe World Health Organisation has claimed we are not adequately prepared for a global flu pandemic, with experts saying it “is a matter of when, not ”. In a statement issued earlier today, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus claimed the threat of pandemic influenza was “ever present”, warning the public not to underestimate the risks. He said: “We must be vigilant and prepared - the cost of a major influenza outbreak will far outweigh the price of prevention.” The last flu pandemic to strike was caused by the HN virus - also known as influenza A - that spread across the world during  and .   According to studies of that pandemic, at least one in five people worldwide were infected during the first year, and is estimated to have caused between , and , deaths globally in the same time. Global health experts and the WHO warn there is a risk that a more deadly flu virus will one day jump from animals to people, mutate and infect many hundreds of thousands of people. Flu viruses are multiple and ever-changing, and they infect around a billion people every year around the world in seasonal outbreaks.  Of those infections, around  to  million are severe cases, leading to between , and , seasonal flu-related respiratory deaths. Vaccines can help prevent some cases, and the WHO recommends annual vaccination - especially for people working in health care and for vulnerable people such as the old, the very young and people with underlying illness. The World Health Organisation’s plan - described as the most comprehensive to date - includes measures to protect the public as much as possible from annual outbreaks of seasonal flu as well as preparing for a pandemic. The plan’s two main goals are to to improve worldwide capacities for surveillance and response - by urging all governments to develop a national flu plan, and to develop better tools to prevent, detect, control and treat flu, such as more effective vaccines and antiviral drugs. During a pandemic, there is little or no pre-existing immunity towards the virus in the human population.  Three influenza pandemics occurred at intervals of several decades during the th century, the most severe of which was the so-called Spanish Flu”. It is believed to have caused an estimated – million deaths in –. Milder pandemics occurred subsequently in  and  known as the Asian Flu”, and the “Hong Kong Flu” in  - they caused an estimated one to four million deaths each.

title: catherine shaw brit backpacker possibly
story: NewsBrit backpacker Catherine Shaw possibly murdered after naked body found in GuatemalaCatherine Shaw, from Witney, Oxfordshire, was last seen leaving the Eco Hotel Mayachik carrying a stray puppyShareCommentsByGerard CouzensChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsCatherine Shaw, , was found dead after failing toto her hotel in Guatemala "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe death of a British backpacker whose naked body was found on a mountainside in Guatemala is being investigated as a possible murder. Catherine Shaws body was discovered on Monday, a week after she was last seen leaving a hostel carrying a stray puppy. It is believed the -year-old, from Witney, Oxfordshire, had hiked from Eco Hotel Mayachik to the Nariz del Indio summit, overlooking Lake Atitlan, to watch the sunrise on March . After the search came to a tragic end, a preliminary police report claimed the Brit was found naked and had visible blows to her body and lacerations on her left leg. Her father had reportedly flown to the Central American country to join the search.   Miss Shaws jacket and trousers, and the puppy were found shortly before her body was discovered near the village of San Juan La Laguna. Community leader Juan Mendoza said the trousers had been found at the Nariz del Indio summit. Mr Mendoza described the -year-old’s death as a crime and called on authorities to find those responsible. Police sources told local press they believed she had been murdered, although officially Guatemala’s PNC force said only it had launched a “criminal investigation” into the “deplorable incident.”  Miss Shaw was found naked near a popular mountain beauty spot called Nariz del Indio - Indian Nose in English - which is a two-hour hike from the hotel she was staying at and is regularly visited by backpackers who travel to the spot nearly ,ft above sea level to watch the sun come up.The peak of the mountain, where a lookout shack with wooden benches has been built which visitors can climb on top of to enjoy a panoramic view of Lake Atitlan, is the tip of the Indian nose and was considered a sacred site by the Mayans who would pray and conduct religious services. Mr Mendoza, revealing volunteers had found Miss Shaw’s body and another search team had found a pair of trousers believed to be the backpacker’s, said: “It’s terrible this type of thing happens in our area and we urge the authorities to investigate because these crimes stain the good name of our municipality.”  A preliminary police report, leaked to local press, said Miss Shaw was found “totally naked, face down and at first sight has visible blows to her body and lacerations on her left leg. A spokesman for Guatemala’s PNC police confirmed she had “several blows” but said the state of decomposition of her body meant it was not possible to confirm how the injuries had been caused at the scene of the find, and forensic experts would have to determine the cause of death. Guatemala’s Interior Ministry said in a statement after Miss Shaw’s body was found: “After several days of intense searching by police authorities, other institutions and volunteers for the missing British national, participating teams are being coordinated at the scene where her body has been found.  “After  hours of an exhaustive search, the result is very regrettable and the Interior Ministry and police chiefs have immediately designated a team which will carry out the criminal investigation. “This is to determine what has happened and who could be involved in this deplorable incident. Miss Shaw disappeared in the early hours of March  after leaving Eco Hotel Mayachik clutching a puppy and leaving her mobile phone and passport behind in her room. The stray dog - shivering but alive - was found at the highest lookout of Indian Nose, near to the spot where her body was found, between am and am on Friday morning. Her distinctive woollen pink and cream jacket has also been found and handed to police.  Miss Shaw had been travelling in Guatemala for two weeks, having previously been in Mexico and Calornia, before she disappeared. She was travelling with a friend, who woke up on the morning of March  to find that she was missing. The Lucie Blackman Trust, which is supporting Ms Shaws family, said on Monday evening that a body had been found which is believed to be Ms Shaws. In a statement it added: The Lucie Blackman Trust is saddened to announce that a body has been found in the search for Catherine Shaw. Formal identication has not taken place but the body is believed to be Catherine. Catherines family have been informed. Please respect their privacy at this dficult time.  The charity said Ms Shaw had left the hotel in Mayachik, near San Pedro and San Juan, on March  at .am, but then ed at .am. She then left again for the last time at .am, heading in the direction of the lake. The trust said that at this point she had a puppy with her but no other possessions. A hand drum, known as a hang, previously reported to be in Ms Shaws possession, was left behind and has been located, and she did not have a guitar with her when she left, the trust added. The search encountered many challenges including communication issues due to lack of power in the area. Friends had set up a Facebook page to help to coordinate the search efforts and raise funds to pay for a helicopter to join the hunt for her.

The first-ever footage of the Filin P- in use was broadcast on the Russian Defense Ministry’s channel Zvezda. It was filmed as the defence technology was tested in St Petersburg and shows the light flashing on and off continuously. One of the Filin P-s was said to be on board the Russias missile frigate Admiral Gorshkov which was spotted off the UK coastline last week.The Royal Navy scrambled a warship, HMS Defender, to follow the Russian naval task group, including the missile frigate Admiral Gorshkov.  HMS Defender intercepted the Russian vessels in waters north east of Scotland and escorted them as they passed the UK coastline and sailed through the English Channel. The Admiral Gorshkov, which is on its maiden mission, is alleged to have been fitted with the Filin P- visual optical interference weapon which can blind enemies and cause nausea, leaving them with feelings of disorientation and hallucinations. It is said the non-lethal weapon fires strobe-like beams to disrupt the enemys vision and prevent an attack, and is part of an arsenal that includes guided Kalibr missiles. Russias Ministry of Defence said the Admiral Gorshkov - named after Soviet Navy Admiral Sergey Gorshkov - is sailing with the supply ship Elbrus, the rescue tug Nikolay Chiker and the tanker Kama.   The Admiral Gorshkov entered service last year and is expected to join Russias fleet of ships in the Mediterranean. HMS Defender, a Type  destroyer equipped with a Sea Viper missile system, was scrambled over the weekend to keep watch on the Admiral Gorshkov and three auxiliary ships. The British warship left Newcastle on Saturday to head northeast of Scotland to meet the Russian task group in time for the ships to pass the UK coastline on Tuesday. A Navy spokesman said: Portsmouth-based Defender is monitoring the Russian task group and keeping track of their activity in areas of national interest.   Armed forces minister Mark Lancaster said: The Royal Navy is always standing ready to defend the UK. We will continue to work with our allies to shadow Russian ships passing through international waters close to our shores, to ensure the Russian navy follows the correct protocol on its journey. The Filin P- has also been installed on Russias Admiral Kasatonov frigate.

title: unforgettable moment premature baby twins
story: NewsMums tears of joy as premature baby twins embrace as theyre finally reunitedZoe and Olivia were born at  weeks and had to spend a month apartShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsIts been a really emotionally-charged time for the new parents "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tiny twins Zoe and Olivia spent  weeks together inside the womb before making their debut into the world.Having never been apart, however, it was at this point they were separated for the first time for a month to prevent one twin from accidentally suffocating the other. It took  days for doctors to be satisfied that the twins were strong enough to be reunited, and the emotionally-charged moment was made all the more poignant when Zoe reached out to hug her older sister. The decision to deliver the girls early was made after doctors were concerned that one of them was in distress.Mum Ann Les pregnancy had been a high-risk one, with her precious girls sharing an amniotic sac.Known as monochorionic monoamniotc twins, this sort of multiple pregnancy means there is only  per cent chance the twins will survive past  weeks.   Throughout her pregnancy from  week mark, Ann, from Melbourne, Australia, had had to have fortnightly ultrasound scans to monitor the girls development.On the day of their delivery, Olivia came first - with a loud cry, Ann tells Daily Mail Australia .Zoe came next but was breech, so after a bit of pulling, the doctor managed to get her out. She didnt cry or move which made us really concerned.  Both girls were quickly taken by the midwives to the paediatric team for assessment. Fast forward a month and Ann was finally able to have a much anticipated twin cuddle. We waited  days exactly for our first twin cuddle and it was so much more than we could have expected, she adds. Olivia was placed on me first, then when it was Zoes turn she reached out her left arm and hugged her sister. My tears were flowing, its a moment Ill never forget. The proud mum shared the beautul moment on Instagram .Now Ann is hopeful that she can take her girls home with her by mid-April. It has been emotionally draining for my husband and I, but now that they have passed the one month mark, their chances of survival are now greater than  per cent, she said.

story: It is estimated one in  babies born in the UK have a type of cerebral palsy.It can occur for several reasons, including a bleed within the baby’s brain, a premature or dficult birth process, limited or interrupted oxygen supply to the brain, the mother getting an infection while pregnant or changes in genes that can affect the development of the brain.Cerebral palsy can affect co-ordination, muscle control and reflexes as well as posture and balance.For more information visit cerebralpalsy.org.uk and for more information on hemiplegia visit hemihelp.org.uk.

title: double boost for dundee united as butcher and sow set to return
story: Dundee United are to receive a double boost for today’s Championship trip to take on struggling Partick Thistle.Midfielder Calum Butcher s from his one-game cup suspension, served last Sunday, while striker Osman Sow is in line to get a place on the bench after injury.Butcher’sshould add some steel to the Tangerines engine-room as they look to get the better of the bottom-placed Jags in Glasgow and, hopefully, close the gap on league leaders Ross County.Swedish hitman Sow has recovered from a calf problem and may be risked at some point this afternoon as United look to find the back of the net from open play after a deluge of penalty-kick goals in recent weeks.Terrors manager Robbie Neilson was delighted to have some key men back and available to choose from.“Butcher’s back in, which is great,” he said.“He brings that experience and that physicality so I’m pleased to bring him in.“Sow is fit. He has trained and will be involved today.“He had a wee calf problem which tightened up last Thursday.“We tried him on the Friday and he just didn’t think it was right, so we felt that it was better just to leave him out of it as opposed to putting him on the bench – bringing him on for  minutes and it blows up after .“I just felt last Sunday wasn’t the right one to put him in but he’ll be available today.“He’s a top player. I knew when I got him that it was going to take a bit of time to build him up and slowly get him where he is but he’s here for a period and there’s no doubt he’s got ability.“It’s just getting him on the pitch and getting him as fit as we can as quickly as we can without injuring him.”And Robbie hopes the -year-old’scan spur United on in the final third in their quest to come away from Maryhill with all three points.Expressing his disappointment about the lack of goals scored lately, he said: “We’ve not scored as many as we would like but when you look at the previous game at home, in the first  minutes, we had four or five chances to put the ball in the net and we didn’t do it.“It will come, we’re creating chances and just maybe not taking them but the most important thing is that you create.”

title: dundee girl says charity could have saved her mum who overdosed at 36
story: A Dundee teen has admitted her mum could have avoided dying from a drugs overdose at just she had sought help from local services.Alana Gowans, , lost her mum Alexis Watson to drugs in September last year, with the pain of the loss still fresh for the college student.But now Alana, who studies early childcare education at Dundee  Angus College, hopes to make a dference after winning a sum of cash to donate to a local charity.The city centre resident had a dficult upbringing as her mum lived a chaotic lestyle, meaning she had to move in with her gran aged just three.Alana said: “It was dferent, but gave me protection from seeing the substance use.“I was quite upset and angry and took it out on my gran sometimes.“My mum had been addicted to heroin since she was  and came off it for so long, but then she started to take Valium and sleeping tablets.“She wanted to get better for me, but it was hard.”Alana recognised there were many other young people across the city going through a similar experience.She said: “I’d say to anyone who is going through a dficult situation to go to the charity Addaction.“Every day is dferent. Some days I blame myself, but she’s in a better place.”Alana, along with fellow students from Gardyne Campus, won a grant for £, after completing a presentation on their chosen charity – Addaction – in front of a  from the Youth and Philanthropy Initiative.The team presented a cheque for the cash during a ceremony at the Addaction centre in Whitfield, while a tree will also be planted in memory of Alexis.Alana, who is hoping to become a nursery teacher after her studies, said: “We had to go to the charity and find out all the information and do a presentation in front of judges.“We didn’t know much about Addaction but last year I realised the support they give.“I think Addaction could have saved my mum.”Dave Barrie, service manager for Addaction, said: “It’s sad but it’s the reality.“It was heartbreaking to hear about. Having that loss is enormous for anyone.“The money will be going towards really good recovery programmes and we’re planting a tree in memory of her mum.”

title: dundee need to pick up points at home says jim mcintyre
story: Home matches against Hearts are where Dundee need to be picking up points, according to manager Jim McIntyre.The Dens boss felt his side were worth at least a point from Saturday’s - defeat to the Jambos but he concedes “it’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t”.There were positives in the performance for the Dark Blues boss as his side created decent opportunities but conceded a poor th-minute winner from Sean Clare.Jim said: “It’s hard to be critical because it’s so scrappy.“It’s not asthey’ve cut us open.“Where I’m disappointed is that we don’t stop the cross but we have men in place and it is an old-fashioned stramash where the ball is stuck between bodies.“They got a toe-poke to it and it was a really frustrating goal, a scrappy, poor goal to give away.”Asked about the chances in the opening minutes of the game, Jim replied: “They are the opportunities you have to take.“Goals give you a real surge in belief but we are showing plenty of spirit because we are conceding the first goal a lot but we are coming back and still at it in the th minute.“At the same time, we are at home and we need to be picking up points against Hearts at Dens.“We had a brilliant result against them at Tynecastle but we want to be picking them up here and I felt there was enough in the performance to deserve at least a point.“It’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t.”

title: dundee people dundee students make splash for hindu festival holi
story: Students at Dundee University added a splash of colour to their campus while celebrating the Hindu festival Holi.The celebration, which took place on Saturday, was organised by the University of Dundee Indian Societyin collaboration with Dundee University Students’ Association .Holi, which signies the triumph of good over evil, correlating with the passing of winter, usually takes place later in March in India.However, students in Dundee hosted the event early in order to fully celebrate the festival ahead of exams.More than  participants – including staff and members of the public – were expected to attend the festivity on Saturday.Nitya, a second-year medicine student originally from Kerala in the south of India, said the festival made her feel “way more at home”.Ahead of the event on Friday, Claire Hartley, vice-president of communications and campaigns at DUSA, hailed the efforts of students celebrating the festival in Dundee.

title: dundee people girls have a ball at primary schools festivals
story: Primary schoolgirls had a ball at the latest football festivals held in the city.Two festivals got under way last week, with the first taking place on the articial pitch at Craigie High.Nine teams from Barnhill, Claypotts, Wormit, St Joseph’s, St Andrew’s, Forthill, Fintry and Ballumbie primary schools played against each other in the fun-filled event.The second festival was held at the DISC two days later, with eight teams participating from Rowantree, Craigiebarns, Dens Road, Clepington, St Ninian’s, St Francis, Longhaugh and Rosebank primaries.Although there was a lot of friendly competition between the teams, the festivals were all about having a great time and promoting the girls’ game so there were no winners announced on the day.The two festivals were jointly organised by Dundee United Community Trust, Active Schools Dundee, Leisure  Culture Dundee and the Scottish Football Association.n Picture shows the nine teams who participated in the first festival.

title: ewan gurr this is why dundee council leader john alexander deserves credit after difficult period
story: Councillor John Alexander, the leader of Dundee City Council, has had a dficult month following ongoing criticism and protests over local budget cuts.However, I was impressed to discover the role he and his administration played in enabling Dundee to make a stand as the UK’s first living wage city.Our elected politicians deserve credit when they get it right and, on this, I believe they have.However, it has been a collective effort.Backed by Living Wage Scotland and Poverty Alliance, a cohort of  local employers including Dundee City Council, DC Thomson and Xplore Dundee have voluntarily committed to an action plan that ensures all their staff receive a real living wage of at least £ per hour, above the legal requirement of £., as well as encouraging other local employers to commit to doing likewise.The announcement took place in the vista room at the top of the DC Thomson building, with a panoramic view of Dundee in the background.Addressing a packed room, Mr Alexander said: “Living wage accreditation is not the only tool we have to overcome poverty, but it is one mechanism.”He later added: “This is as much about social, as well as physical, regeneration and having pride and confidence in your city.”

title: Bags of help at North Kessock beach clean
story: A MAJOR Black Isle beach clean against the backdrop of one of the peninsularsquos most recognisable landmarks recovered  bags of waste, among it syringes, plastic and fishing lines.It is the fth time a group led by Greenpeace volunteers from Inverness has cleaned the beach at Scarabs at North Kessock near the Kessock Bridge.Greenpeace activists ldquoadopted the beach via the Marine Conservation Society with the idea of not only cleaning up on a regular basis, but also monitoring results over a longer period.David Smith, of Greenpeace Inverness, said: ldquoWe had a great turn-out which I think was due to online shares, it was really good to have so many people along.The community beach clean attracted around  volunteers, among them Highland Green MSP John Finnie.Mr Finnie said: ldquoIt was a very successful day. It seemed to be very well attended which was great as it felt like we were all part of a community effort.Mr Finnie went on to say that although these litter clean-ups were essential, the long-term goal should be to stop littering altogether: ldquoIdeally we want a situation where people are not dropping any litter. Prevention is better than cure.Among the litter picked up from the popular recreational area were six used syringes which Mr Smith believes were washed up rather than dumped there.A spokesman for Highland Council said: ldquoMost pharmacies offer a free needle disposal service. Failing that, people can put them in a safe container and take them to out to the waste management team at Lotland Street. Discarded needles should not be taken to recycling centres as they are classed as special waste.Greenpeace Inverness was established in October  and has supported the organisationrsquos national and global campaigns.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: High Life Highland boss retires
story: The chief executive of High Le Highland , the biggest leisure services provider in the region, has announced his intention to retire from the top job in the summer.Ian Murray has been the boss of the charity since it was created by Highland Council in October  when it was tasked with delivering and developing the local authorityrsquos culture, learning, sport, leisure and health and well-being services.Since then it has grown to employ more than  full and part-time staff and support more than  volunteers with an annual turnover of pound million.Mr Murray first moved to the Highlands  years ago to take up the position of depute director of leisure services with what was then Ross and Cromarty District Council.When Highland Council was formed in  he moved to the region-wide remit of head of community learning and leisure before leading the transition of those services to High Le Highland seven years ago.Mr Murray said: ldquoLeading the transition to High Le Highland and the seven years since has been the most challenging, rewarding and enjoyable period in my career.ldquoSince HLH began, visitor numbers have grown almost three fold, annual income has doubled, reliance on council funding reduced by half and HLH has been asked by the council and several community groups to adopt  additional services, from the formerly community-run pools in Bettyhill and Poolewe to more recently the councilrsquos school music tutor service.ldquoI have been very fortunate to have been supported throughout by a very motivated, professional and innovative team across everything we do.HLH was recently the centre of tensions over funding as Highland Council drew up its budget and sought to make cuts that saw the price of HLH membership rise by around pound. In draft budget papers, a move to increase the revenue target by pound. million was tabled but later removed.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Smoking not wanted at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Smokers could soon be made unwelcome around the entrances to Invernessrsquos historic Victorian Market as part of a drive to smarten up the appearance of the shopping arcade.The market itself is officially a smoke-free zone, but two letters sent out to traders asking them not to light up around the entrances have had no effect, it was reported at a meeting of the tradersrsquo association recently.Now market manager Jo Murray is investigating whether it would be legal for the smoking bins currently placed at the entrances to be removed in the hope that this will discourage smokers from congregating there.The meeting heard that among the smoking ldquoculprits at the Church Street entrance to the market are patrons of the neighbouring Market Bar, which shares an access close with the Victorian Market.Mrs Murray admitted: ldquoUnfortunately nothing can be done at the Market Bar entrance as it is private.ldquoHowever, I am checking with the fire service to ensure there is no legislation preventing the fire bins at other entrances being removed.ldquoDropped cigarette butts might become a problemthere are no bins, but litter wardens can fine offenders.The tradersrsquo association meeting agreed that removing the smoke bins at the entrances might help improve the image of the market.It was also agreed that all future Victorian Market literature will also declare it a smoke-free zone.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: sponsored tired of waiting weeks for appointments welcome to aberdeens newest walk in beauty salon
story: Fed up trying to book a nail, lash or brow appointment months in advance so you can get it at a time to suit you  Well, now there’s a solution, thanks to one of Aberdeen’s newest beauty salons.Lash and Lush opened its doors last month and for co-owner Jenna Young, it was vital that the salon suited its clients’ needs, not the other way round. vw, px"  “I’ve been a working mum for the past  years and it’s been so hard to get appointments, unless I booked weeks and months ahead of time.“But even then, with kids your schedule can be unpredictable so that always wasn’t the best way to do things.“I also thought that it would be good for a salon to be open on a Sunday, because people tend to have a bit more time on Sundays.”And in December Jenna decided it was time to make her wishes a reality for other women in Aberdeen.Just over a month later Lash and Lush was up and running. vw, px"  Open six days a weekpeople can just turn up and get treatments.“We don’t take appointments, it’s walk in only, which means you don’t need to wait weeks for an available space.”The team of four highly experienced beauty therapists offers nails , eyelash extensions and volumising, and eyebrow waxing, threading, tinting and henna brows. vw, px"  “Henna brows are a natural way to create a new shape of an eyebrow, or to enhance eyebrows that are pale or have gaps.“And until the end of the month, you can get henna brows for just £.”Jenna added: “Each member of the team focuses on dferent treatments, but every one of them works hard to give customers the look they want.”Lash and Lush is open from am until pm on Tuesdays and Wednesdays and pm on Thursdays and Fridays. On Saturdays they open at am and close at pm and between am and pm on Sundays.Find out more about Lash and Lush on their Facebook page.
